rationale: Ongoing surveys indicate that Melanochelys tricarinata is widespread and occurs in localised substantial and secure populations in part of its range. There are reported declines particularly in the eastern part of its range, these likely amount to 50% of the total species’ population over three generations spanning the past and future. Moreover, the species has been subject to a steep increase in (illegal) international pet trade in recent years. Its area of occupancy has not been quantified.
habitat: Melanochelys tricarinata is a near-terrestrial species that inhabits the grasslands along the Ganga and Brahmaputra at the foot of the Himalayas and the moist deciduous and wet evergreen forests of the nearby foothill areas up to about 300 m altitude (Das 1991, Schleich and Kästle, 2002). The species apparently is semi-fossorial and active mainly during the wet season; it appears to prefer stream edge habitats (Lucknow Red List Workshop participants Sept. 2005). Diet in the wild is unrecorded, captives accepted a variety of animal and vegetable foods (Das 1991). Up to three clutches of 1–3 large eggs have been reported (Das 1991, Schleich and Kästle 2002). Estimated age of maturity is about five years; generation length of about 15 years.
threats:
Habitat destruction and exploitation for subsistence consumption have been recorded in the eastern part of the range of Melanochelys tricarinata in India (Das 1991, Choudhury et al. 2000). Forest and terai habitat loss in Nepal was considered a significant impact on the species (Lucknow Red List Workshop participants Sept. 2005).

This is apparently the species of choice for the manufacture of curio masks widely sold in tourist and craft markets in South and locally in Southeast Asia (Mitchell and Rhodin, 1996, Choudhury et al. 2000).

In recent years, M. tricarinata appears to have become highly popular in the Asian pet trade, with significant numbers being seen in market surveys and some 2,000 (at least 1,979) live specimens, in at least 15 shipments, having been reported as seized from illegal trade during the period 2000-2015 (CITES CoP 17 Doc 73). Seized specimens recently include large old specimens, indicating collecting efforts affecting core range areas. All marked Wildlife Institute of India (WII) animals have disappeared (about 120 marked animals, usually about 20–30 encountered per year; no shells found, i.e. unlikely to be local mortality).

There have been confiscations in recent years of this species within both Hong Kong and Bangladesh (presumably animals coming from the Indian terai) (P. Praschag and S. Singh pers. comm. 2018).
population: Melanochelys tricarinata is considered localized, often uncommon, though sometimes locally abundant, especially in Dehradun, Uttaranchal, India (Choudhury et al. 2000; Das 2009). One study found 48 specimens in two years. In Nepal, surveys at a protected area in the terai resulted in 36 specimens found in a 3-month survey effort (Participants Red List Workshop Singapore 2011). Participants of the Tortoise and Freshwater Turtles of Tropical Asia Red List Workshop in Singapore (2018) reported population declines particularly in the eastern part of its range, these likely amount to 50% of the total species’ population over three generations spanning the past and future.
range: Melanochelys tricarinata inhabits the Himalayan foothill from western Uttar Pradesh to Arunachal Pradesh of northern and northeastern India (with an isolated occurrence in southern Bihar / western West Bengal) and southern Nepal (Iverson 1992, Das 1995, Choudhury et al. 2000). It doubtfully occurred in Bangladesh (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: Melanochelys tricarinata is collected for the subsistence and international food trade. Also, it is sold as pets on international markets and used to create curio masks.
conservationActions:
Melanochelys tricarinata is included in CITES Appendix I, prohibiting all forms of international commercial trade. Melanochelys tricarinata is also protected under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances, under license from both federal and provincial authorities (its older synonym Geoemyda tricarinata is listed in Schedule IV, requiring only a small game hunting license to allow collection and local trade). The synonymised name Geoemyda tricarinata should be transferred to IWPA Schedule I.

It has been recorded from several protected areas, including Kaziranga National Park (Assam), Orang WLS (Assam), Dudhwa TR and Corbett TR (UP) in India (Hanfee 1999), and Simlipal Tiger Reserve, and Royal Chitwan in Nepal, and the Whykong Forest Reserve in Bangladesh. Status surveys, with emphasis on occurrence in effectively protected areas, are needed. Studies of natural history are desirable. Reducing subsistence consumption is desirable, while use for tourist trinkets and illegal pet trade probably need to be limited. Surveys in isolated parts of the species range maybe reveal previously unidentified populations. Identified areas of occurrence require protection. Public education in regions where the species is consumed locally may also be beneficial (Das 2009).

rationale: Eutropis clivicola is endemic to southern Western Ghats of Kerala. Since its discovery in 1984 it has been reported from four localities (each treated here as a separate location) and it has an estimated extent of occurrence below 2,000 km2. The habitat of this species in some parts of its range has undergone drastic changes due to anthropogenic factors including tourism related infrastructure development, logging, illegal mining for precious stones, conversion of forested tracts into commercial plantations and forest fires, and declines in habitat quality are ongoing. This species is therefore listed as Endangered, although if further surveys reveal that it occurs more widely its assessment status will need to be reviewed
habitat: Members of this species have been collected on a road and on a bare patch of land in a secondary forest area, and on large rocks in open spaces in tea plantations (Inger et al. 1984). It occurs in lowland plantations and moist deciduous forests (S. Pal pers. comm. March 2011) and has also been recorded from evergreen forests (A. Roy pers. comm. March 2011).
threats: The hill ranges from where the species is known are facing a decline in quality of habitat due to anthropogenic activities including logging, illegal mining for precious stones, conversion of forested tracts into commercial plantations and forest fires. Since the discovery of this species in 1984, the type locality Ponmudi has undergone numerous changes (as it is a major tourist destination) that include laying new approach roads for the Ponmudi Hill resort and tourist centre, forest and undergrowth clearing for tourism related development activities, heavy vehicular traffic during peak tourist season.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of this species.
range: Eutropis clivicola is endemic to the southern Western Ghats of Kerala, India. It is known from Ponmudi (Thirivananthapuram District) (Sharma 2002), Peechi (Thrissur District) (Joseph and Easa 1997), Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary (Palghat District) and Athirapalli-Vazhachal (Thrissur District), all in Kerala (A. Roy pers. comm. March 2011). All known records were taken at elevations ranging from 260 to 350 m asl (Inger et al. 1984). The lizard has an estimated extent of occurrence of 1,897 km2.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. As Eutropis clivicola is known from a few areas close to the type locality, further surveys are recommended to establish its distribution.

rationale: Dasia subcaerulea is known from Bodinayakkanur, in High Wavy mountains near Chinnamanur and on the banks of Thambiraparani & Sarvalar rivers in Kalakkad-Mundunthurai Wildlife Sanctuary, Tamil Nadu, India. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 5000 km2. The forest habitat where it occurs has undergone drastic changes in the past 60 years and anthropogenic pressures to the habitat such as tourism and increase in human settlements may be likely threats to this species. The species is therefore listed as Endangered.
habitat: The second known specimen was collected after a forest fire, indicating that the species might have occurred in forest tracts near Bodinayakannur, Theni district, Tamil Nadu. This site is presently characterized by tropical dry deciduous type of forest. Additional specimens have been found in reasonably well-preserved broad-leaved galley forests along the banks of rivers in Mundhunthurai (Joshua and Sekar 1984). It is a diurnal and arboreal species that has been reported to show preference for undisturbed habitats, although one specimen from Mundhunthurai was recorded in the Forest Department maintained dormitory (Karthikeyan 1991).
threats: The quality of this lizard's apparent dry forest habitat has undergone drastic declines in extent and quality over the past 60 years (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2013), due to residential development, tourism and associated development. Bodinayakanur is now a human settlement. Smith (1949) reports that the second specimen was partly damaged due to a forest fire. The impacts on this species are unclear, however it has only been recorded from relatively well-preserved forest. Most of the species' known localities fall within protected areas, however declines in habitat quality have been recorded within one of these sites, Kalakkad Mundunthurai Wildlife Sanctuary, and so the extent to which protected areas benefit this species is uncertain.
population: Dasia subcaerulea is known from just two specimens collected in the High Wavy Mountains, and from "quite a number" of additional records elsewhere in Tamil Nadu (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011). It appears not to have been recorded at all between 1949 and 1984. No information on population trends is available. Studies specifically looking for this species since 2007 have not rediscovered it in the High Wavy Mountains.
range: Dasia subcaerulea is endemic to Western Ghats, India. Until recently it was thought to be known from only two sites in the High Wavy mountains and Bodinayakanur, Theni District, Tamil Nadu, India (Smith 1949), with no more recent recorded sightings. Specimens recorded since 1984 have, however, been misidentified as D. haliana (see Wickaramasinghe et al. 2011), which is known from records taken from two sites within Mundanthurai Wildlife Sanctuary, both in the Tirunelveli District of Tamil Nadu (Joshua and Sekar 1984, Karthikeyan 1991), and from Kalakad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve (Johnsingh 2001, Kumar et al. 2001). A recent record from Kudremukh (Vasudevan et al. 2006) needs to be verified. This species has an estimated extent of occurrence of 3,054 km2. It occurs at elevations between 300 to 1,500 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place. It occurs in protected areas, and parts of Kalakkad Mundhunthurai Tiger Reserve are reported to be well-managed, although changes in habitat quality have been recorded within the reserve. Studies specifically looking for this species between 2007 to 2010 have not resulted in locating it in the High Wavys or in Bodinayakanur, however following recent taxonomic clarification further surveys should be conducted at known sites and in additional areas of Tamil Nadu. More information is needed on the natural history of this poorly-known lizard, and its exposure and sensitivity to threats.

rationale: Cnemaspis goaensis is known from three locations, one each in Goa and Karnataka. Though general threats to this species are not known the areas from where this species is reported have undergone a decline in quality of habitat. The extent of occurrence is less than 1,000 km2, and though possibly an underestimate, is believed to be definitely less than 5,000 km2.  It is therefore assessed as Endangered.  It is recommended that more studies are needed to establish its distribution and impacts of threats on the species.
habitat: This species is reported to be common in the moist deciduous forests near Cotigao village, South Goa, Goa,  and Mathigatta Village in Uttara Kannada, Karnataka. Nothing is known about the ecology of this species except   that it seems to be a humid forest dweller and its population is locally abundant (V.B. Giri pers. comm. March 2011).  It is found commonly under rotting logs and stones, bark of trees, and on walls of habitation (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011).
threats: Little is known about the threats to this species. However, the sites from where it is reported are facing a decline in quality of habitat due to anthropogenic activities including infrastructure development like housing and roads.
population: After the type description from Poinguinim, Canacona taluka in South Goa, Goa (Sharma 1976) where it has been reported as uncommon, Cnemaspis goaensis has been reported from the vicinity of Cotigao village where it is locally abundant (V.B. Giri pers. comm. March 2011).  It is very common in forests and near habitation (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011).
range: Cnemaspis goaensis is endemic to India and is known from the forests of Poinguinim and Cotigao in Canacona taluka, South Goa, Goa (Sharma 1976) and Mattigattha, Uttara Kannada, Karnataka (S. Sondhi in litt. February 2011).  It has also been recorded from Cotigao Wildlife Sanctuary (V.B. Giri pers. comm. March 2011).  The estimated extent of occurrence between the known localities is less than 1,000 km2.  However, this is probably an underestimate, partly due to the spatial configuration of the three known localities. This species occurs at elevations between 50 to 100 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Cnemaspis goaensis is known from one protected area -- Cotigao Wildlife Sanctuary in South Goa.  Its distribution range needs to be established.

rationale: Cnemaspis wynadensis is known from Silent Valley National Park and Wyanad in Kerala, two locations where it is has an extent of occurrence of less than 5,000 km2.  The quality and extent of forest habitats from which this lizard has been reported are declining due to expansion of human habitation and commercial agriculture, and it is therefore is assessed as Endangered.
habitat: Cnemaspis wynadensis is known from tropical evergreen forests in the Western Ghats (Das and Bauer 2000).
threats: Nothing is known about the specific threats to this species. However, the hill ranges from where the species is known are facing a decline in quality of habitat due to expansion of agriculture, human habitation and tourism related activities.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of this species.
range: Cnemapsis wynadensis is endemic to Western Ghats, India. It is known only from two sites, namely from Wayanad and Silent Valley National Park, Palakkad District, Kerala (Smith 1935, Das and Bauer 2000, Bauer 2002).  The extent of occurrence is less than 5,000 km2. There is a report from Sasthanada, Thiruvananthapuram District, Kerala (J. Jose pers. comm. March 2011), which may be a species closely related to C. wynadensis. Other reports in the southern Western Ghats include Parambikulam, Kavalai, Cochin and Thrissur (Tikader and Sharma 1992) need evaluation. It occurs at elevations between 1,800 to 2,500 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Cnemaspis wynadensis is known from Silent Valley National Park, Kerala. There is clearly a need for improved habitat protection at the type locality, Wayanad, Kerala. Further survey work is needed to establish its distribution.

rationale: Ahaetulla perroteti is endemic to Nilgiri Hills in the Western Ghats. Though general threats to this species are not known the areas from where this species is reported have undergone a decline in quality of habitat due to anthropogenic pressures and due to conversion of grasslands into commercial plantations. Its extent of occurrence is about 1,820 km2 it is therefore assessed as Endangered.  It is recommended that more studies are needed to establish its distribution, ecology, populations status and impacts of threats on the species.
habitat: Ahaetulla perroteti occurs in grasslands in shola patches. The breeding season of this ovoviviparous snake is reported to be between July to September (Wall 1919). It is not known from modified habitats.
threats: Grasslands in the Nilgiris have been converted over the last 100 years to pine, eucalyptus, tea and wattle plantations. There is a decline in the quality of  its remaining habitat due to anthropogenic disturbance.
population: Ahaetulla perroteti can be common within its restricted range.
range: Ahaetulla perroteti is endemic to the Nilgiri Hills of the Western Ghats, India. It has been reported from grassland patches in shola forests (Beddome, R.H. California Academy of Sciences Herpetology Collection, Ganesh, S.R. (in litt.) dt. 10.01.2011, Chandramouli, S.R. (in litt.) dt. 12.02.2011, Achyuthan pers. comm.) between 2,000 m to 2,800 m asl. There are doubtful records from outside of the Nilgiri Hills (Smith 1943, Ishwar et al. 2001, Zacharias 1997).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Ahaetulla perroteti is a rare colubrid endemic to the Western Ghats. It occurs in Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve. Further survey work is needed to understand its ecology, population status and trends.

rationale: Rhinophis travancoricus is known from five sites from the states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu, each treated here as a separate location. It is thought to prefer soft soils and the area from which it has been reported has witnessed soil compaction, rapid expansion of commercial plantations, agriculture and human settlements, due to which the quality and quantity of habitat has declined and will continue to do so in future. The extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of this species based on the few known records is less than 500 km2, hence this species is assessed as Endangered.
habitat: Rajendran (1985) reports this snake from forested tracts and rubber plantations, in regions experiencing fairly warm climate with summer temperatures well above 20°C. It is burrowing snake.
threats: The current distribution of this species is largely under cultivation. A study (Rajendran 1985) identified two new subpopulations in yam and rubber plantations and indicates that the species is restricted to soft soils left untouched by planters. Unlike other hardy uropeltids these were not encountered in hard soils of plantations. Decline in habitat quality due to habitat conversion for commercial plantations and soil compaction seems to be a major threat to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Rhinophis travancoricus, which is known from only five records and has not been recorded since 1972.
range: Rhinophis travancoricus is endemic to the Western Ghats, India and is known from three historic localities (one each in Kottayam, Idduki, and Thiruvananthapuram districts) in Kerala (Wall 1923, Smith 1943), and two recent localities (Muathupuzha in Kerala, and Ambadi-Vannaparai in Tamil Nadu; Rajendran 1985). It has been recorded at elevations between 0 and 1,200 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species is currently not known from any protected area, but further surveys are needed in protected areas nearby where it has been recorded (Peppara, Neyyar, Shendurney, Periyar, Idukki and Thatekkad). It is a unique example of range-restricted species with a wide altitudinal range, it is a species of soft soil and conversion of habitats for commercial plantations appear to have negatively affected this species. Research is needed to establish its population trends and identify the threats.

rationale: Eurylepis poonaensis  is known only from the type description and from recent collections at three additional localities in Pune and Satara Districts, and has an estimated extent of occurrence between these localities (each considered to represent a single locations based on threats from rapid urbanization and tourism) of 1,324 km2. The habitat at the type locality and in its vicinity is threatened due to rapid urbanization and tourism, representing a continuing decline in the extent and quality of the lizard's habitat, and this species is therefore listed as Endangered.
habitat: This lizard occurs in grasslands and scrub jungles in the hill ranges in and around Pune and nearby temple towns in Poona district and Satara district.
threats: The hill ranges of Pune and Satara districts are under heavy pressure from rapid urbanization and tourism related developmental activities.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species, and each of the recent site records is represented by only a single specimen.
range: Until recently Eurylepis poonaensis was known only from the type locality in Katraj Ghat, Pune District, Maharashtra, India, from where it had not been collected since 1970. Between 2006 and 2007, specimens were collected from Saswad, Chatursinghi and Katraj in Pune District, and from Jaijuri in Satara District, by Vivek Gour-Broome (S. Thakur pers. comm. March 2011), increasing its known distributional extent to 1,324 km2. It occurs at elevations between 600 and 800 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place. As the majority of site records for this species are recent, it is likely that its distribution is still incompletely known, and thorough surveys are required to obtain additional records within Maharashtra. Research is recommended to clarify this lizard's taxonomy, natural history and responses to urbanization and tourism. Protection of grassland and scrub forest habitat within this rapidly-developing area may be necessary.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that it has an extent of occurrence of 2,500 km2 encompassing two locations defined by a threat from land clearance and, while it is relatively common within its restricted distribution, there are threats from forest fires and forest management practices that are causing a decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, and which may cause local population declines.
habitat: Otocryptis beddomii is a small sized terrestrial lizard commonly encountered among leaf-litter and forest floor vegetation in the Western Ghats. In the Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary, the maximum number of juveniles sightings were in October (Jose et al. 2007).
threats: Otocryptis beddomii has been recorded around Myristica swamps area in southern Kerala (Jose et al. 2007) and this habitat was under threat due to conversion into agriculture lands and betelnut gardens. At present, clearing the forest edges for firelines disturbs the microhabitat of this species (Jose et al. 2007).
population: It appears to be common in some lowland forests bordering Myristica swamps. In Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary and Kulthupuzha in Kollam district, Kerala the population density of this species was reported to be 4.25 individuals per hectare (Jose et al. 2007). Chandramouli (2009) reports that this species occurs in high abundance in the mid-elevation rainforest (300-600 m)
range: Otocryptis beddomii is endemic to the Western Ghats, India. It has been reported from Sivagiri Ghats in the Cardamom hills, Kerala, Ponmudi, Thiruvananthapuram district, Kerala, Anchal Forest Range, Kollam district, Kerala, Kulathapuzha, Kollam district, Kerala, Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary, Kollam district Kerala, Kalakkad Munduthurai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1935, Inger et al. 1984, Johnsingh 2001, Jose et al. 2007, Chandramouli 2009). This species occurs at elevations between 150 and 1,100 m asl. The species has an estimated extent of occurrence between known sites of 2,500 km2; its area of occupancy, assuming that it occurs over a 50 km2 area at each known locality, is taken to be 700 km2.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species occurs in three protected areas, which comprises most of its distribution.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has a known area of occupancy in India (20 km<sup>2</sup> based on records of subpopulations known to be extant) and due to its specific restriction to a highly threatened habitat that survives mainly due to efforts to conserve the Black Buck, it is not likely to have a much more extensive area of occupancy in India, and very small areas of remnant habitat remain at each locality, with more than half of the historically known localities having been lost over the last century, it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat at each remaining Indian locality and in at least part of the presumed Sri Lankan range. This assessment is based on Indian records, and may consequently be precautionary, pending clarification that recently discovered Sri Lankan subpopulations correspond to this species, since while this is thought likely to be the case this assignment is in need of validation.
habitat: This species has been recorded from species of dry, sandy scrub-clad lowlands (Ganesh and Chandramouli 2010) devoid of rocky outcrops, including areas close to the seashore (Ganesh et al. 2017). Srikanthan et al. (2018) recorded it from both grassland and dry thorn scrub, as well as in coconut groves and paddy fields. The historic record of this species in Sri Lanka is from coastal sand flats (A. Bauer pers. comm. March 2011). Species distribution modelling suggests a preference for low-elevation areas with a mean annual temperature of around 28.5 °C, rainfall below 1,000 mm a year, and relatively little difference between maximum and minimum temperatures (Srikanthan et al. 2018). It is strictly terrestrial and nocturnal, and shelters beneath rocks during the day (Srikanthan et al. 2018). In Sri Lanka it occurs in the arid zone, where it has been found beneath stones and logs in sparsely-vegetated scrub on sandy soils, and has been found in retreat sites by day (D. Jayesekara pers. comm. 2019). It exhibits strong evidence of territoriality and intraspecific aggression, with individuals separated from one another by 15-20 m (Srikanthan et al. 2018). Ganesh et al. (2017) reported that gravid females were active both in July, in the pre-monsoon season, and following the monsoon in December an February.
threats: Habitat loss in the form of burning of grasslands and conversion into real estate, grazing and tapioca plantations, and multiple invasive plant species that increase fire risk and shade its sandy habitats. Prosopis is the most widespread of these, affecting most formerly suitable open habitat within its range. Sand quarrying in and around river beds and coastal dunes are causing population decline. The known distribution is almost entirely human-modified. This species only survives at all because of efforts to conserve the Black Buck along the Coromandel coastal plains, a species which is dependent on similar grassland habitat. Urban development and rural settlement threaten the species in Sri Lanka, although it occurs in habitat in this country that is not generally subject to major threats; on Mannar Island there are multiple widespread threats including wind power and tourist industry development.
population: This species is poorly-sampled and underrepresented in collections (Bauer et al. 2010). Ganesh and Chandramouti (2010) reported the first record in over a century; other literature reports had previously been overlooked as they misidentified the species as the similar Hemidactylus reticulatus (Ganesh et al. 2017). It is an apparently rare species (Srikanthan et al. 2018), however in Tuticorin these geckos are reasonably common under boulders in fallow land at the three known sites (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011). Ganesh et al. (2017) recorded 14 individuals in 55 man-hours of fieldwork across six localities. Declines have been observed in Coimbatore and Tuticorin (Srikanthan et al. 2018).  Five of the nine Indian localities are known to have been lost over a period of about a century. Near Trichy, all original habitat has been lost and the species no longer survives here. The species can no longer be found at a historical locality, Adayar, following urbanisation in Chennai (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). The Coimbatore locality was destroyed in 2018, and if the lizard survives here at all it is thought to be confined to a 17 acre temple complex (N. Achyuthan pers. comm. 2019). Recent records from Sri Lanka have been of small numbers of individuals: three within one hectare at Mantai, and three in Chundikulam.
range: This species is found in Tamil Nadu in India, and in Sri Lanka. In Tamil Nadu this species is known from Adyar, near Chennai (Chennai District), Ramanthapuram (Ramanathapuram District), Mannampandal (Nagapattinam District) (Ganesh and Chandramouli 2010) and Tuticorin (Tuticorin district) (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011, Ganesh et al. 2017). Ganesh et al. (2017) and Srikanthan et al. (2018) report multiple new localities across the south of the Indian peninsula ranging from the coast to the foothills of the Western Ghats and the Coimbatore Plateau. Species distribution modelling suggests that the species could range more widely in dry areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala (Srikanthan et al. 2018). The gecko was historically recorded from Mariccukatte (=Marichchukkaddi) in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka, based on a record of three specimens (Smith and Deraniyagala 1934). Taylor (1953) reported that he did not find this species, it has not been found in a survey of Sri Lanka's northern islands (De Silva 1957), and the only recent published report of its occurrence in Sri Lanka (in the northernmost tip of the Eastern Province) is not accompanied by any exact locality data, known specimens, photographs or ecological information (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Srikanthan et al. (2018) report that no recent records exist from this country, however, recent unpublished records have been taken in 2016 from Chundikulam National Park (D. Jayesekara and M. Wickramasinghe unpubl. data) and in 2018 from Mannar Island and Uramalai (Dulan Vidanapathiratna and S. Kannishka pers. comm. 2019). Photographs taken by D. Madhavi in 2018 Giant's Tank, close to Mannar, are likely to represent this species (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). It has been recorded from 10 to 385 m asl in Tamil Nadu (Srikanthan et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species, which is not known to occur in protected areas in India other than a single, 14 km<sup>2</sup> protected area Vallanadu Wildlife Sanctuary near Tuticorin. In Sri Lanka it appears to occur in the Giant's Tank Sanctuary. Further research into the taxonomy and distribution and biology of this gecko is needed, and into its exposure to threats. Recognition of grasslands and shrublands as important wildlife habitats maintained without afforestation is recommended (N. Achyuthan and S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). Field surveys in Pt. Calimere Sanctuary are recommended to try to identify whether it occurs here. Mostly unprotected in Sri Lanka.  It is entirely dependent on continued management of known sites for its survival in India. Taxonomic research is underway (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019) to clarify whether recently rediscovered subpopulations in India and Sri Lanka are conspecific. Thorough evaluation of Sri Lankan records, including collection of specimens, is needed, and clarification of its distribution in this country and the extent of threats.

rationale: Platyplectrurus madurensis has been assessed as Endangered as it has restricted distribution both in extent and attitudinal range with an extent of occurrence and area of occupancy less than 1,000 sq km and 100 sq km, respectively. It is known only from a few records and is affected by decline in quantity and quality of habitat as there has been extensive deforestation and habitat loss in the area (two locations) where the species had been recorded.
habitat: This species is fossorial and inhabits forests and gardens (Das 2002). Sightings from gardens and tea plantations (three records between the 1970s and 1990s) are from historically forested areas. It is ovoviviparous, producing four to five young in June and July (Das 2002).
threats: Extensive deforestation and habitat loss have occurred in the areas of the historical records, likely indicating a decline in the quantity and quality of suitable habitat. Pesticide use in commercial plantations and tourism-related development activities may also negatively impact this species. The Palani Hills is a tourism spot where considerable infrastructure development has taken place and at Cardamom Hills, new commercial crop plantations have been established.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species. Wall (1923) and Rajendran (1985) reported collecting this snake from Shembaganur, Palni Hills.
range:
Platyplectrurus madurensis is endemic to the Western Ghats (India) with records from Palani Hills, Tamil Nadu and Cardamom Hills, Kerala at altitudes between 1,200 and 1,800 m above sea level (Smith 1943). This species has been collected from Shembagnur and Nyamakad (Rajendran 1985) in the early 1970s and photographed in the wild recently (Das 2002).
The previous (2009) assessment of this species indicated that it also occurred in Sri Lanka. This occurrence has not been confirmed and it is based on a single specimen found in a collection of snakes sent by Rev. P. Abraham of St. Alosius' College in Galle. This specimen was the basis for the description of subspecies ruhunae. But the bottle contained specimens from both Sri Lanka and from Madras in India (R. Somaweera pers. comm. 2013) , hence there is some confusion as to whether or not there is a confirmed specimen of this species from Sri Lanka (there may be Sri Lankan specimens at the Natural History Museum in London). Most experts, however, believe that the species does not occur in India and that belief forms the basis of the information presented in this assessments.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species does not occur in any protected area. Further research is needed on the distribution, population size and trends, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,337 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat as well as in number of mature individuals in the Western Ghats.
habitat: This species is found in forest fragments or sholas between villages, towns and settlements (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). It has been recorded in tea plantations in Valparai and Munnar (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020 ). Individuals have been found in late evenings after heavy rain, from forest undergrowth about 2 m above the ground (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Like other congeners, this species breeds by direct development.
threats:
Continuing habitat loss due to small and large-scale agriculture (tea, orange, cardamom and other crops) and logging are threats affecting the species' habitat. In particular, potentially suitable breeding habitat is continuously being destroyed in Kaikatti-Nelliyampathi (S.D. Biju pers. comm. May 2011). Tourism is also affecting this species in Vagaman (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). In the Sabarimalai area, a mass pilgrimage of millions of people occurs on an annual basis which causes pollution to terrestrial habitat, species disturbance, and there is an annual burning of the 1 km2 of grassland for use as a seating area by the pilgrims (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). The species is used sporadically for medicinal purposes, although this is not considered to be a major threat to the species. Climate change is a potential future threat which may result in the shifting of habitat, and subpopulations that already exist in higher elevations may be lost as they have no habitat to migrate to (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). 

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
population: It is now infrequently encountered compared to 2004, when it used to be common in the localities where it was found (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). It is now considered to be locally abundant (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). It is restricted to remnant forest habitat throughout its range, and there is lack of connectivity between more than half of the known localities due to the unsuitable habitat of the surrounding agricultural matrix. Its population is therefore assumed to be severely fragmented. Its dispersal capacity is believed to be low due to its habitat specialization. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from Tamil Nadu and Kerala states in the Western Ghats of India. In Tamil Nadu, it is known from Valparai, and its vicinity in Coimbatore district (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021). In Kerala it is known from Chinnar, Devikulam, Kadalar, Mathikettan, Mattupetti (Garg et al. 2021) and Munnar in Idukki District (S.D. Biju pers. comm. February 2014), and in Kaikatti-Nelliyampathi in Palakkad district (Garg et al. 2021). It occurs between 600-1,800 m asl. It may be found between known localities (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,337 km2.
useTrade: This species is used as medicine for coughs, as general medicine for children and as amulets for children who do not speak or walk well (Kanagavel et al. 2020).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Anamalai Tiger Reserve and Mathikettan Shola National Park, however most of its population is outside protected areas, in private and forest lands owned by the government (S.D. Biju pers. comm. December 2010).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, its dispersal between habitat fragments ,and the effects of climate change and Bd. Population monitoring is also recommended (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

rationale: This species has a very restricted distribution in the Shilong Plateau of northeast India (extent of occurrence (EOO) = 1,385 km<sup>2</sup>) and it occurs in five locations, based on the main threat to its population. There is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to the expansion of urban areas. It is therefore listed as Endangered.
habitat: On the Shilong Plateau, where remaining natural habitat is dominated by grassland with isolated trees and small patches of tropical moist forest on hill slopes and around perennial streams (Giri et al. 2019). Based on observations taken over the course of a year, this species favours forest edges and, where it occurs in grassland, is found on isolated trees or large bushes (Giri et al. 2019). A female was found to contain six eggs (Giri et al. 2019).
threats: The main threat is habitat loss from urban expansion that is impacting the tropical moist evergreen forests where the species occurs.
population: It is infrequent on the Shilong Plateau based on observations taken over a year (Giri et al. 2019).
range: Giri et al. (2019) redescribed this species and clarified that it is known with certainty only from the Khasi Hills in Meghalaya state in northeast India. This is likely to correspond to the original collection locality, which was given as "Affghanistan" but has been considered likely to be in error by a number of authors (Giri et al. 2019). A reported collection from Sikkim, also regarded as questionable by previous authors (Smith 1935) is likely to result from misplaced labels, as the collectors visited both Sikkim and the Khasi Hills (Giri et al. 2019). It has been reported from Motuo, in southern Tibet (Zhao and Adler 1993), but this requires further confirmation (Giri et al. 2019).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It has not been recorded within protected areas. Research is needed to better determine its distribution, natural history, population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it. Awareness and capacity building is recommended as it is confused with a more common Calotes species.

rationale: Vijayachelys silvatica is listed as Endangered, as there are probably fewer than 2,500 mature individuals, and there is expected to be a continuing decline of about 20% in the population over the next two generations largely through collection for subsistence use, but also potentially through habitat loss from hydropower development and forest fires. It is difficult to justify a 50% decline in population over the past three generations, although there has been significant habitat conversion in the Western Ghats of India over the past 70+ years.
habitat: Vijayachelys silvatica is a terrestrial species restricted to evergreen and moist deciduous forest, mainly in hilly areas between 400 and 800 m. Animals spend their time mainly hidden among leaf litter, alongside tree buttresses, roots, lianas, fallen logs and other vegetation, or in tree holes or burrows (Das 1991, Deepak et al. 2014). These turtles are active, alert predators that feed on forest floor invertebrates, mainly insects and snails, as well as on fruits and other vegetable matter (Das 1991, Deepak et al. 2014). Adult females have a carapace length of 11.4–13.9 cm and weigh 76–340 grams, males are  smaller at 10.0–12.6 cm carapace length and 84–275g; hatchlings measure 37–40 mm carapace length (Deepak et al. 2014). Age of maturity may be about eight years; a generation length is estimated at 24 years (based on three times the age of maturity); it is difficult to estimate the age of longevity. Females produce one to two clutches, typically of two eggs, but a range from one to four eggs has been reported (Moll et al. 1986, Deepak et al. 2014). Females lay eggs in narrow crevasses under log and bark, and do not dig nesting chambers nor cover the nest with substrate or leaf litter (Das 2010).
threats:
Vijayachelys silvatica is recorded as threatened by past forest destruction through logging and subsequent establishment of tea, coffee, cardamon and opium plantations and through wildfires (Das 1991). Much of the remaining habitat for this species is within protected areas. Forest fire impacts on the habitat remain a problem (Andrews pers. comm. 2005). Hydroelectric reservoir construction is likely to affect areas inhabited by the species; 24 reservoirs have been created in Kerala alone, with another 12 in the planning stage (Deepak et al. 2014). Climate change is likely to have significant impacts as the species is very temperature-selective and has minimal opportunity to move to suitable habitat at higher altitudes.

These turtles are collected for subsistence consumption by various native groups in the area, sometimes using dogs to find them (Das 1991, Deepak et al. 2014). The species is understood to be in the illegal wildlife trade, though it has not been formally recorded in international trade, and has not been reported among trade seizures since at least 2000 (CITES CoP17 Doc73).
population: Vijayachelys silvatica is an uncommon and sparsely distributed species: an encounter rate of one turtle per four person-hours searching by experienced collectors has been recorded. This is partly due to its cryptic nature (Groombridge et al. 1983). More populations continue to be discovered with ongoing survey efforts, but the quality of the habitat required by the species generally is in decline (Lucknow Red List Workshop Participants Sept. 2005). By 2011, the species was understood to be represented by good populations documented within protected areas, based on surveys by Wildlife Institute of India staff. Its occurrence appears to be patchy; in presumed optimal habitat with minimal human disturbance, encounter rates of about one turtle per six hours were documented, with density varying between 0.1 and 0.83 turtles per hectare (Deepak et al. 2014). Given current information it is suspected that there are fewer than 2,500 mature individuals (Participants Singapore Red List Workshop 2018). At least a 20% decline in the population over the next two generations is expected due to collection for subsistence use, but also potentially through habitat loss from hydropower development and forest fires.
range: Vijayachelys silvatica is endemic to the southern Western Ghats mountains of India (Das 1991). from southern Karnataka, Kerala and western Tamil Nadu.
useTrade: It is collected for subsistence food as a Non Timber Forest Product (NFTP).
conservationActions:
Vijayachelys silvatica (as Heosemys silvatica) is protected under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances, under licence from both federal and provincial authorities. It was included in CITES Appendix II in 2013.

Vijayachelys silvatica has been reported from Peechi-Vazhani (125 sq km), Neyyar (128 sq km), Idukki (70 sq km), Peppara (53 sq km), Aralam, Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuaries (285 sq km), and Kothayal Forest Reserve (all in Kerala), as well as Anamalai (841 sq km)- Indira Gandhi Wildlife Reserve (117 sq km, TN), Kalakad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve (665 sq.km, Kerala-Tamil Nadu), Karian-Shola National Park (TN), Mookambika Wildlife Sanctuary (Karnataka), Neria Forest Reserve (Agume) and other protected areas in southern Karnataka (Das 1991, Hanfee 1999, Deepak et al. 2014; Participants Lucknow Red List Workshop Sept 2005).

Ensuring the continuing ecological integrity and connectivity of the protected areas inhabited by the species is crucial to the species’ survival; this includes careful consideration of the impacts on the species by proposed hydroelectric development projects. Increased awareness among protected area managers and staff about the species’ occurrence and conservation needs will be very helpful, possibly including outreach materials emphasizing the species’ unique and attractive features. Dogs need to be excluded from protected areas. NTFP collection to be monitored and supervised. Options to reduce subsistence consumption by native groups should be explored. Further status surveys, population monitoring and further natural history and conservation biology studies, possibly including research on captive specimens, are desirable. Phylogenetic work on the species and genetic lineages is desirable.

rationale: The species is recorded only from a few locations in the Chhota Nagpur region. The species is restricted in its extent of occurrence of less than 5,000 km². Threats include severe fragmentation, loss of habitat, loss of habitat quality, and indiscriminate collections by several European pet traders because of its beautiful colouration. It is therefore categorized as Endangered.
habitat: The species is found in mixed deciduous forests.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation are major threats. Collection for international pet trade in addition to the other threats is of concern for this species.
population: Population information is not available. The species is rare, and is similar to other Poecilotheria species in its patchy distribution. Found in less than 10 locations, some of which are very severely fragmented.
range: Poecilotheria miranda is endemic to the Chhota Nagpur region of eastern India up to an altitude of 800 m. The extent of occurrence encompassing known and inferred distribution is less than 5,000 km², while the area of occupancy is less than 2,000 km². In West Bengal: Kharagpur Hills (Gravely 1915); in Jharkhand: Near Chaibassa in Singbhum (Gravely 1915); Chota Nagpur (Pocock 1900).
conservationActions: It is likely that this species occurs in Simlipal Tiger Reserve but further surveys are required to confirm its occurrence.

rationale: The species is restricted to fewer than five fragmented locations in the southern Western Ghats. The species suffers from the threats of habitat degradation and loss due to continuous cutting of old trees for timber and collection of minor forest produce. In Kerala, the locals kill the wandering males that venture into homes and/or found on trees out of fear. The population is also threatened since there is pressure from pet traders in smuggling this species out of the country into Europe and America. This spider can be found on various pet websites. It is categorized as EN because of its restricted range (less than 5,000 km²), and because it is found in less than five fragmented locations and is threatened with continuing decline in area and habitat quality.
habitat: The species was found in a degraded moist deciduous and evergreen forest. It has been reported from teak plantations and sometimes enters human settlements. Nothing is known of its breeding biology.
threats: Major threats are habitat loss, degradation and pet trade. As the species is highly restricted to the Western Ghats, if the habitat loss continues then it is likely that this species could go extinct. Pet traders collect this spider from forested areas near Trivandrum.
population: Population information is not available. The species shows more of the same trends in patch distribution like other species of the genera. Only six subpopulations have been reported from six locations.
range: Endemic to the southern Western Ghats, this species is found in the Trivandrum area in the south at an altitude of less than 500 m. The extent of occurrence encompassing known and inferred distribution is less than 5,000 km², while the area of occupancy is less than 2,000 km². In Kerala: Trivandrum (Pocock 1899, 1900), Ponmudi, Kallar, Peppara Dam (Smith and Kirk 2001); in Tamil Nadu: Agastyavanam Reserve (Smith and Kirk 2001).
conservationActions: It is reported from in and around Agastyavanam Reserve. It is assumed that it occurs in reserve forest and private plantation near Trivandrum. Captive breeding is not very successful without continuous influx of wild individuals and thus pet trade will continue (Capannini 2003, Ezendam 2003). Therefore, the species requires protection at the national level by being included in the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act. It is also important that this species and all other Poecilotheria species from India and Sri Lanka are included under the CITES Appendix II to safeguard them from trade.

rationale: The species is recorded from southern Western Ghats. The habitat other than the protected area where the species occurs is completely degraded due road cutting or expansion, and logging of wood. The pressure on the forest is increasing. It is assumed that the area of habitat in one known location and the inferred range has decreased over the years. The population is fragmented and found in less than five locations. This species is categorized as Endangered because of its small range, its occurrence in less than five fragmented locations and due to continuing decline in area and habitat quality.
habitat: The species was found in moist deciduous forest and evergreen rainforest. These spiders prepare burrows on roadside bunds and requires vegetation cover over the bund. Nothing is known of its breeding biology.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation are major threats. The recent records of the species are only from protected areas. Surveys outside Parambikulam and Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuaries did not reveal the presence of this species, which implies its dependence on protection and preservation of habitat. An additional threat to the species is collection by international pet traders, which could have an impact on the population. The two threats in tandem could result in the species' extinction from the known location in the near future.
population: Population information is not available. Its distribution is patchy as seen in the case of other ground theraphosids.  Further surveys are required to understand abundance and population size in various areas. It is found in less than five locations with severe degree of fragmentation.
range: Haploclastus kayi is endemic to the Western Ghats of India, this species is found in Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary (WLS) in the north and Tenmala in the south at an altitude of 200 to 700 m. The extent of occurrence encompassing known and inferred distribution is less than 5,000 km², while the area of occupancy is less than 2,000 km². In Kerala: Parambikulam WLS in Palakkad district (Gravely 1915, 1935; Manju Siliwal and Sanjay Molur pers. obs.), Tenmala in Thiruvananthapuram district (Binu Arthur and Manju Siliwal pers. obs., Molur and Siliwal 2004); in Tamil Nadu: Indira Gandhi WLS (10°26'2.6"N, 76°50'13.7"E) in Polachi district (Sanjay Molur and Manju Siliwal pers. obs., Molur and Siliwal 2004).
conservationActions: The species occurs in the Parambikulam and Indira Gandhi Wildlife Sanctuary in southern India. Further surveys are required to know their presence in other protected areas in southern India. The species requires protection at the national level by being included in the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act.  It is also important that this species is included under the CITES Appendix II to safeguard it from unsustainable trade.

rationale: The species is recorded from only three sites in two areas of the highly degraded Eastern Ghats. The habitat where the species occurs is completely degraded due to lopping for firewood and cutting for timber. The species is highly restricted in its extent of occurrence (less than 5,000 km²) and area of occupancy (less than 500 km²) with past and continuing decline in extent, area and quality of habitat. The population is additionally threatened by human interference in the form of persecution, collection for pet trade and other developmental activities.
habitat: Forests in these areas are of dry deciduous type with few patches of moist forests. No information is available on this species from the wild in last hundred years except for information on trade.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation are major threats in the reported and inferred localities of the species. It is likely that in many localities the species would have gone locally extinct due to complete deforestation, logging of wood, forest fire and development activities. Given the habitat threats and restricted distribution, collection for international pet trade from the few remaining populations is an additional pressure on the extant populations.
population: Population information is not available. Although reported from three localities these reports are nearly a hundred years old. The locations are severely fragmented. No surveys have been conducted in these areas to establish the status, but considering the species to be closely related to other Poecilotheria species, their behaviours and ecology, we assume that the species has declined due to loss of habitat and degradation in quality of habitat in the Eastern Ghats.
range: Poecilotheria formosa is endemic to the southern Eastern Ghats between Salem and Tirupathi in southern India; reported only from three locations, altitude of less than 1,000 m. The extent of occurrence encompassing known and inferred distribution is less than 5,000 km², while the area of occupancy is less than 500 km² and could be even less than 100 km² due to extensive loss of habitat. In Andhra Pradesh: Renigunta station (Smith and Kirk 2001); in Tamil Nadu: Kadiampatti, Mullapuram in Salem District (Pocock 1900a,b)
conservationActions: This species has not been reported from any protected area. The species requires protection at the national level by being included in the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act. It is also important that this species and all other Poecilotheria species from India and Sri Lanka are included under the CITES Appendix II to safeguard them from trade.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its population size is estimated to number fewer than 2,500 mature individuals, there is an observed continuing decline in the number of mature individuals, and no subpopulation contains more than 250 mature individuals.
habitat: The Nilgiri tahr is found at high elevations on cliffs, grass-covered hills, and open terrain (Nilgiri Tahr Trust, retrieved 03 January 2007).  Females gestate for about 180 days, and usually give birth to one kid per pregnancy (Rice, 1984). Animals are sexually mature in the wild at around three years of age (Wilson, 1980; Rice, 1990), though they are only expected to live three or 3.5 years on average, their potential life span is at least 9 years (Rice, 1988; Rice, 1990). The species is diurnal, but are most active grazing in the early morning and late afternoon (Prater, 1971; Nowak, 1991).
threats:
Principal threats are habitat loss (mainly from domestic livestock and spread of invasive plants) and poaching (Daniels et al. 2008). The general trends of decline even in the best managed Tahr habitats indicate that the total population of the species does not exceed 2000 at present and a conservative estimate would place the numbers within the 1,800-2,000 range (Daniels et al., 2006). Currently, the only populations with more than 300 individuals are in Eravikulam National Park and in the Grass Hills in Anamalai. The most recent information from the Nilgiri hills (Mukurti Wildlife Sanctuary), which previously had more than 300 tahr (Davidar, 1978; Rice, 1984; Schaller, 1971), indicates that only between 75 and 100 individuals remain. Wattle (Acacia mearnsii) plantations and cattle apparently no longer threaten the Mukurti population, so their decline is probably due solely to illegal hunting. The status of the other smaller populations (many of which are less than 100 individuals), which are also subject to continued illegal hunting, can be considered precarious. Similar population decreases and threats to the species were reported in a survey in Kalakad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve (Rai and Johnsingh, 1992).

Populations of these animals are small and isolated, making them vulnerable to local extinction. Habitat patches for Nilgiri tahr are naturally discontinuous, but some habitat fragmentation may have anthropogenic causes (C. Rice pers. comm., 2008). The species faces competition from domestic livestock, whose overgrazing has allowed for the invasion of graze-resistant weedy species into preferred meadows, thus in competition with the native grasses that tahr prefers (Mishra and Johnsingh, 1998). Continued conversion of tahr habitat to agricultural land has resulted in a present distribution that is about one-tenth of its historical range (Mishra and Johnsingh, 1998; Kannery, 2002; IUCN, 2004).
population: Total numbers were estimated at between 2,000 and 2,500 individuals in the 1970s-1980s, and were thought to be stable (Davidar, 1978; Rice, 1988a, 1990). More recently Daniels et al. (2008) estimated the total population at no more than 1,800-2,000 individuals. An overall decline in the species was suggested by Daniels et al. (2008), although some populations appear to have remained stable in recent decades (Mishra and Johnsingh 1998). The species current populations are estimated to be Nilgiri hills (450, though now reduced to 75-100), Silent Valley (30), Siruveni Hills (20), Elival Mala (60), Nelliampathi Hills (30), Top Slip and Parambikulam (120), Eastern Slopes of Ananmala (125), Grass Hills of Anamala (250), Swamaimala (130) Eravikulam National Park (760), High Range (30), Palani Hills (60), Highwavy mountains (100), Mudaliar oothu (70), Vellakaltheri (90), Ashambu Hills (70), and Thiruvannamalai peak (40) (Nilgiri Tahr Trust, retrieved 02 January 2007).
range: The present distribution of the Nilgiri tahr is limited to approximately 5% of the Western Ghats in southern India, in Kerala and Tamil Nadu in southern India (Shackleton, 1997; Grubb, 2005), although not along the border between these two states (M. Alembath pers. comm. 2007). At the beginning of this century the range of tahr probably extended northward at least to the Brahmagiri hills of southern Karnataka (Shackleton, 1997).  The animals are more or less confined to altitudes of 1,200 to 2,600 meters (Nilgiri Tahr Trust); populations as low as 900 m may or may not represent pre-human extent of occurrence in elevation (Rice, 1984).
conservationActions:
The Nilgiri tahr is fully protected (Schedule I) by the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972, although this protection is rarely enforced and illegal hunting is a major threat (Kannery, 2002; IUCN, 2004).

The creation of Eravikulam and Silent Valley National Parks, Mukurti, Anamalai, and Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuaries, and Srivilliputhur Grizzled Giant Squirrel Sanctuary and the Kalakadu-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve, together offer an important degree of protection to the Nilgiri Tahr. Eravikulam National Park and its surroundings has been cited as having nearly 1,000 individuals (Kannery, 2002), although others have questioned this figure, believing it to be too high (Abraham et al. 2006, M. Alembath pers. comm., 2008).

The Tamil Nadu Forest Department is removing exotic monocultures along the periphery of the Mukurti National Park. In addition, institutions such as the Nilgiri Wildlife Association, High Range Wildlife Association, Ramnad District Wildlife Association, Kerala Forest Research Institute, Bombay Natural History Society and the Wildlife Institute of India, are active in promoting conservation of Nilgiri tahr. Conservation measures proposed: The Nilgiri tahr requires continuous study and monitoring, because its small and isolated populations are extremely vulnerable. With proper conservation, including habitat maintenance and minimising mortality due to hunting, it is possible that with time, the species could be considered no longer threatened, if the following are accomplished: 1) Establish the proposed Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve. This would include the Bandipur, Nagarhole and Silent Valley National Parks, the Mudumalai, Mukurti and Wynad Wildlife Sanctuaries, the Bolampatti Reserved Forest and the proposed Karipuzha National Park (WCMC, 1988c), and encompass a Nilgiri tahr population of 400 to 450 individuals (Davidar, 1978; Rice, 1984). An extension to such a reserve has also been proposed (Rice, 1990) to include peripheral cliffs used by tahr as escape and birthing terrain. A revised biosphere reserve design of these conservation units has been suggested by Rodgers and Panwar (1988). 2) Enact management proposals that include the systematic monitoring of tahr populations, as well as possible re-introductions (Rice, 1988a, 1990; Rai and Johnsingh, 1992). There is good potential for re-introductions in areas such as the Kalakadu-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve where several highlands had small populations of tahr some 20 to 40 years ago, but today are very small or non-existent (Rai and Johnsingh, 1992). 3) Consider low impact recreational use (e.g. trekking, fishing) of suitable areas, especially where such activities would benefit (and compensate) the local economy for restrictions on traditional activities such as hunting by local inhabitants. 4) Co-ordinate Nilgiri tahr with other wildlife and habitat conservation efforts, because the Western Ghats are one of India’s major wildlife areas.

rationale: Semnopithecus ajax is listed as Endangered as the population is very small, estimated to be less than 1,500 mature individuals in 15-20 subpopulations with no subpopulation having more than 150 mature individuals. Previously, the species was thought to be restricted to Chamba Valley with an extent of occurrence (EOO) smaller than 5,000 km², and an area of occupancy (AOO) smaller than 500 km². However, the populations in Jammu-Kashmir fit into the morphological and behavioural patterns of the type locality population, thereby these are now included within the S. ajax assessment. This additional range has increased the EOO and AOO for the species, but the number of mature individuals within the known distribution is still restricted and declining.
habitat:
This species is found in pine, moist temperate and alpine cedar forest from 1,300 to 4,000 m. It is folivorous, diurnal, and mainly terrestrial (Molur et al. 2003).

Multimale-multifemale type social organization. Unimale-multifemale and all male bands have also been observed. Typically, these langurs are found in groups ranging between 25-40 individuals. But occasionally, as in one case in Chamba, they numbered over 100 individuals. In Dachigam, groups of over 500 individuals are seen together in congregation for a brief period during winter, after which they disperse into smaller groups (Mehreen Khaleel pers. comm.). Seasonally variable diet but often found feeding on Rhododendron arboream, Aesculus indica, Quercus leucotrichophora, Pyrus pashia, Berbers asiatica, Rubus spp..,Urtica spp., Abies pindrow and crops like Zea mays (Maize), Pyrus malus (Apple) and Raphanus sp. (Radish) (Vishal Ahuja pers. comm.). In Dachigam, they have been found feeding on bark/peel of Ulmus villosa and Ulmus wallichiana. They also feed on seeds of Rhus succedanea and Pinus wallichiana in winters. Walnut (Juglans regia) also forms a large part of their diet in the months of August-September. They also known to lick mud and rocks. Cultigens are a substantial part of the diet. They are primarily arboreal but also spend a good part of their time on the ground. Infants with a more dark, brown fur were observed around March/April, so birthing could be around this time. In Dachigam, the greatest number of infants were found during Jan-March. Very little inter-group or intra-group aggression, if any, were observed. During the months of Nov-March when the groups fuse together, behaviour such as aggression (showing of teeth), chasing away the male, and mating take place. The animals, unlike their lowland congeners, do not vocalize the characteristic langur whoop but rather have a deep, grunt like bark. In Chamba they range from about 1,300 m to 3,000 m in sub-alpine cedar and oak forests (Anandam et al., pers. obs.). In Kashmir, they range from about 1,600-3,000 m and prefer broadleaved deciduous forest habitats, one or two solitary males were found at 3,500 m during summer.
threats:
Molur et al. (2003) list the following past threats: overgrazing, building roads through forests, logging, deforestation, agriculture, and fire. Present and future threats include agriculture and development (Molur et al. 2003).

The booming tourism industry around prime habitats like the Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary is a serious threat. Unregulated tourism has ushered in some unwelcome practices such as non-biodegradable garbage disposal, tourist resorts and food-stalls or Dhabas, and loud vehicles through the park. Other such places around the state are now being identified as tourist hotspots therefore the threat is spreading to places new and far. Logging and lopping are other activities in the region but the impact of such activities on the population has not been assessed (Anandam et al., pers. obs.).

Crop foraging is a growing threat across Chamba. In the 2012-2013 survey, 76 of the 244 sites surveyed across the district reported agricultural crop foraging and about 25% of the respondents expressed negative attitude towards langurs (Anandam et al. 2013b). In Kashmir, villages nearby Dachigam, Overa and Hirpora WS reported negative intraction in the form of crop foraging during winter (Dec-Feb) and early spring (March-April). Survey conducted from 2015-2017 in eight districts of Kashmir namely; Pulwama, Srinagar, Anantnag, Shopian, Ganderbal, Bandipora, Budgam and Baramulla reported crop foraging in 7 out of 87 villages. In places close to Dachigam, people retaliate by throwing stones to shoo away the langurs back to protected area.

Due to change in land-use, people have started to grow apple orchards and vegetable farms in villages close to protected areas. This can be considered as a growing cause of crop raiding in places close to Dachigam. For the past three years, villages in Kangan area (District Ganderbal) in Kashmir have reported solitary males foraging on apple and walnut trees. These are usually single males or two. People show neutral attitude towards their presence as no large-scale damage was reported. Only 5% people reported conflict in the entire valley and shoo away monkeys from their fields.
population:
Molur et al. (2003) estimated a total population of this species as fewer than 500 individuals (250 mature). The valley where it lives is surrounded by snow peaks and therefore it has remained isolated from other langurs, and the population is very small (M. Singh and C. Groves pers. comm). With the recent information from Dachigam National Park and other places within the Kishtwar Valley of Jammu-Kashmir indicating the population to be S. ajax, the numbers are estimated to be less than 1,000 mature individuals in the Kishtwar Valley. Dachigam holds the maximum number of mature individuals whereas, at other places the average troop size was found to be around 20-25. The total number of mature individuals is estimated to be less than 1,500 in number. Decline in the past is not known but it is predicted to decline by less than 10% in the next 10 years (Molur et al. 2003).

There are very little data available on the population in Chamba, owing primarily to the steepness of the terrains and shyness of the langurs. But given the many developmental activities in the region, the consequent pressures on the forests, increasing negative interactions with humans, and increasing attacks of the langurs by dogs, one could safely presume that the population is threatened and potentially decreasing (Vishal Ahuja, pers. comm)
range:
This species is reported as occurring in northwestern India in Himachal-Pradesh and Jammu-Kashmir (Groves 2001). It is claimed by Brandon-Jones (2004) that this species occurs in Melemchi, Nepal. Morphological and behavioural studies indicate its occurrence is restricted only to the Chamba Valley in Himachal-Pradesh and Kishtwar Valley in Jammu-Kashmir. The species range is restricted (<10,000 km²), and therefore also its area of occupancy (<2,000 km²).

Following Pocock's (1928) description, the species is identified only from Chamba (Groves and Molur 2008). All the other populations are considered under the plausibility of variation and hybridization and therefore cautiously await taxonomic scrutiny and verification. Groves (2001) suggests a wide distribution range for the species, from Dehra Dun in the Doon Valley of Shiwaliks to Pakistani Kashmir. But Groves and Molur (2008) restrict the species to Chamba. The report of the species in Machiara National Park in Pakistan by Minhas et al. (2011, 2013) requires verification for species identity. Recent reports of the species from Dachigam National Park in Jammu-Kashmir in India (Mir et al. 2015, Mehreen Khaleel pers. comm., Junaid Shah pers. comm., P.O. Nameer pers. comm.), confirm the identity of the populations to match morphologically with the Chamba Sacred Langurs. The Dachigam population also lack whooping calls, exhibit grunts and teeth grinding like that of the Chamba Sacred Langurs (Mehreen Khaleel, pers. comm.). Therefore, the distribution here is restricted to Chamba and Kishtwar Valleys in western Himalaya. Based on photographs and direct sightings, the langurs from these places in the Kashmir Valley match morphologically with S. ajax: Wangat-Naranag CR, Kazinag NP, Rajparian NP, Overa WS, and Tral CR, all within Jammu-Kashmir.
useTrade: The species is not used for any purpose.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and Schedule II Part I, of the Indian Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 amended up to 2002 (Molur et al., 2003). Except for Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary, its occurrence in other protected areas is difficult to determine owing to taxonomic uncertainty. The following areas are in need of research: taxonomy, life history, survey studies, limiting factor research, behavioural ecology. The following management actions for the conservation of this species are needed: wild population management, monitoring, public education, and limiting factor management (Molur et al. 2003).

The Himalayan Langur Project, established in 2012, is working across Chamba, with local communities and other stakeholders to establish a holistic conservation program and research on the langur. At present, the project is working with farmers around the Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary to establish sustainable, non-lethal crop-raid deterrents and crop protection strategies (Anandam et al. 2013b).

In Jammu-Kashmir, the species occurs in the following protected areas: Dachigam NP, Wangat-Naranag CR (District Ganderbal), Kazinag NP (Baramulla District), Rajparian WS (Anantnag District), Overa WS (Pahalgam District), and Tral WS (Pulwama District).

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered as the population size is estimated at <250 mature individuals; and because available information indicates that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is smaller than 5,000 km², it is found in no more than five locations, and there is probably a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is suspected due to persecution and hunting for meat.
habitat: This species is mostly terrestrial and has been sighted in a range of habitats, including: degraded broadleaf forest, degraded open scrub forest, agricultural areas, undisturbed oak forest, and undisturbed conifer forest (Sinha et al. 2005). This species occurs at altitudes between 2,000 and 3,500 m (Sinha et al. 2005). It is relatively tolerant of humans, and has occasionally been recorded close to villages and crops (Sinha et al. 2005).
threats: These animals are sometimes killed in retaliation for damaging crops (Sinha et al. 2005). In general, however, the local people do not eat primates (Sinha et al. 2005). Some hunting of primates for meat is carried out by non-local government employees (Sinha et al. 2005). According to Sinha et al. (2006b), 54 macaques were killed in one village over a year in West Kameng district. There is not much habitat loss within its range.
population: According to one source, currently thirty-five distinct troops are known, with at least 569 different individuals (32 troops of 540 individuals in Tawang, and 3 troops of 29 individuals in West Kameng, Kumar et al. 2008; Sinha et al. 2006a). Another source, however, has the number of mature individuals as less than 250 (A. Kumar pers. comm).
range: This recently described species is reported from the high altitudes of western Arunachal Pradesh, northeastern India (Sinha et al. 2005). The type locality is Zemithang (27°42’ N, 91°43’ E, at 2,180 m), Tawang District in Arunachal Pradesh (Sinha et al. 2005). It is distributed over much of Tawang District, and in the western part of West Kameng, they may also occur in other parts of Arunachal Pradesh, and in adjoining areas of Bhutan and Tibet (China) (Sinha et al. 2005). The extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species, based on the available field data, is about 3,700 km² and its area of occupancy (AOO) is about 2,700 km² (Kumar et al. 2008). Macaques resembling Macaca munzala have recently been observed in areas adjacent to Mouling National Park in Upper Siang District, Arunachal Pradesh; however, the taxonomic identity of these animals needs confirmation (A. Kumar Chhangani pers. comm).
useTrade: This species is hunted for meat.
conservationActions: As this is a newly described species, it is not yet listed on the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (Sinha et al. 2005, 2006a), but is covered by CITES Appendix II. Sinha et al. (2005) suggest the establishment of community awareness and conservation programs, as well as the designation of a protected area that is locally appropriate. At the moment it is not known to occur in any official protected areas, its occurrence in Mouling National Park is likely but needs to be confirmed (A. Kumar pers. comm).

rationale: Lion-tailed Macaque is listed as Endangered as the total number of mature individuals is less than 2,500, with no subpopulation having more than 250 mature individuals. There are estimates of a continued decline of over 20% of the populations in the next approximately 25 years, along with hunting, road kills and continued loss of habitat.
habitat:
Mainly arboreal, this species prefers the upper canopy of primary tropical evergreen rainforest (Singh et al. 2002) referred to as Sholas but may also be found in monsoon forest in hilly country with canopies reach 30 to 50 m and in disturbed forest. It is even known to persist in areas with human planted fruit trees such as Jack fruit, guava, passion fruit, and others, although populations fluctuate based on fruit tree availability within a forest fragment. They range in elevation from 100 to 1,800 m (Molur et al. 2003).

The species seems largely to be a seasonal breeder, with births temporally clumped along with the fruiting season dictated by monsoonal climate (Singh et al., 2006). In the wild females first give birth at about 80 months, and have an interbirth period of about 34.3 months. The generation length is approximately 13 years.
threats:
The major threat to this species today is habitat fragmentation, with many of these fragments being further decreased. In the past, habitat loss was due mainly to timber harvest and the creation of exotic plantations such as tea, eucalyptus and coffee. Habitat degradation seems to the biggest threat to the conservation of Lion-tailed Macaques wherever they occur in Kerala (Easa et al. 1997). In private forests and plantations, change in land use is a problem for the species. Hunting is a second major threat, especially in certain parts of its range. In one location, Coorg, with a large area of remaining wet evergreen habitat, the species is highly threatened by non-subsistence and subsistence hunting for food (Kumara and Singh 2004). In some areas, primate meat is preferred as food, and so the animals face serious hunting threats (Kumara and Singh 2004). A local trade exists for pets (Molur et al. 2003), and in Coorg the animals were often hunted in the past for “medicinal” uses.
