Historical accounts suggest the species is uncommon, rarely observed and occurs at low densities (Philips 1981, Roberts 1977). In the Potohar Plateau, Pakistan, Irshad et al. (2015) estimated population density based on counts of active burrows between 2010 and 2013. Across the four districts studied estimated density declined by ~79% between 2010 and 2012 (Irshad et al. 2015), which has been attributed to illegal capture and killing for international trade in pangolin scales (Mahmood et al. 2012). Similarly, in 2012 estimated densities comprised 0.37 ± 0.12 individuals/km² in Chakwal, 0.12 ± 0.08 individuals/km² in Jhelum, 0.10 ± 0.00 individuals/km² in Rawalpindi, and 0.33 ± 0.24 individuals/km² in Attock (Irshad et al. 2015). Using the same method, Mahmood et al. (2015a) estimated an average density 0.36 individuals/km² in Margalla Hills National Park, and 0.00044 individuals/km² in Maneshra district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province, Pakistan (Mahmood et al. 2018). However, it should be noted that there are limitation to the methods used here; it can be inferred from other species of pangolin that this species likely uses multiple burrows in a very short period and as such these estimated should be treated with caution (see Willcox et al. 2019 for discussion on methods).

In Sri Lanka, Pabasara et al. (2015) estimated population density at Yagirala Forest Reserve in the southwest of the country  to be 5.69 individuals/km2, based on modelling camera trap records without identification of individual animals (see Rowcliffe et al. 2008). This is potentially an underestimate based on known exploitation of populations in the area. These densities are far higher than anywhere else in the species’ range and may be due to habitat differences, i.e. tropical lowland rainforest supporting a broader and more abundant prey base. Overexploitation of populations by excessive hunting may have almost eliminated pangolins from some parts of the country (P. Perera, pers. comm).

There are no quantitative population data available for India, Nepal or Bangladesh though it can be inferred and/or suspected that populations in each range state are in decline based on indiscriminate and apparently increasing rates of exploitation. Challender et al. (2019) estimated that between 2000 and 2018 around 300,000 Asian pangolins were trafficked internationally, though it is difficult to accurately quantify how much of this illegal trade involved the Indian Pangolin. There are contemporary records of the species in various protected areas (see the Geographic Range setcion). Further research is needed to determine the status of populations in all range states, including Bangladesh, and the impact of exploitation for local use and international trafficking.
range:
This species is distributed in South Asia from northern and southeastern Pakistan through much of India south of the Himalayas (excluding far northeastern portions of the country), southern Nepal, and Sri Lanka (Prater 1971, Roberts 1977, Schlitter 2005, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012). The species is likely to occur in northern and western Bangladesh (A. Ghose and S. Trageser, pers. comm.). Some reference works refer to the occurrence of the species in Yunnan Province, southwestern China, but there is no evidence to support this, and there are no records from Myanmar (Mahmood et al. 2019).

This species is very locally distributed in Pakistan but has been recorded in all four provinces. In the north it has been recorded in Sialkot, Jhelum and Gujrat Districts in Punjab, extending across the Salt Range into Kohat District, and from Attock District (formerly known as Campbellpur) up to Mardan and Peshawar in the North West Frontier Province (Roberts 1977). There are also records from before 2009 in Nowshera and Swabi (F. Abbas, unpubl. data). It has also been found in the Potohar Plateau Range upwards into the Himalayan foothills (up to 750 m asl). This species is also present in the districts of Kotli, Mirpur and Bhimber in Azad Jammu and Kashmir (R. Hussain, unpubl. data). There are records of the species within the last five years from the Indus River floodplain, including the districts of Bhakar and Jhang (F. Abbas, unpubl. data). Further south there are records from the hilly regions in the western part of the Dadu and Larkana deserts (Sindh), extending southward through Las Bela and Mekran. It also occurs east of the Indus in Hyderabad district and Tharparkar, extending eastwards to Kutch (Roberts 1977).

Widely distributed in India from the Himalayan foothills to the far south, except the far northeast (Tikader, 1983). There are records from Uttarakhand, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand, Delhi, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Chhattisgarh, and West Bengal (Agrawal et al. 1992, Choudhury 2001, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012). The northeastern limits of distribution are not well understood. Choudhury (2001) reports that an individual was caught in Nagaon district, Assam in the 1990s. The is the eastern most record of the species, and it possibly occurs in Meghalaya (Agrawal et al. 1992). There is a record from Manas National Park (Goswami and Ganesh 2014) where the species appears to be sympatric with the Chinese Pangolin. There are records from Odisha and Mishra and Panda (2012) recorded the presence of the species in nearly half the 30 districts in the state.The Indian Pangolin occurs in Maharashtra, Karnataka, Goa, Andhra Pradesh. There are historical records from Kanyakumari, and Kerala; the species also occurs in Tamil Nadu (Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu, 2012).

In Sri Lanka, the Indian pangolin is found locally throughout the lowlands, up to 1,100 m asl, coinciding with the range of termites (Phillips 1981). Recent distribution records suggest that the species is distributed in all nine provinces of the country, inhabiting environments up to 1,850 m asl, with occurrence records from Nuwara Eliya District (Perera et al. in prep). However, records from the coastal lowlands in Jaffna peninsula are rather scarce. This species has been recorded from all dry zone National Parks of Sri Lanka and  has also been recorded from coastal and near shore areas. 

This species is distributed in lowland areas of southern and western Nepal (Baral and Shah 2008), and is found in a number of protected areas (see the Conservation section). Within Parsa Wildlife Reserve, it is possible the species is sympatric with the Chinese Pangolin. Further reports suggest the Indian Pangolin exists in the Makwanpur District and Terai regions, extending into northern India (DNPWC and DoF 2018).

Khan (1985) reported that the species was extirpated from parts of Bangladesh: Heath (1995) reported that the species had been extirpated from Bangladesh altogether. Trageser et al. (2017) reviewed the status of pangolins in Bangladesh; it is likely that the species occurs in west and northwestern areas. There are records of the species in neighbouring West Bengal in India from 2018 (A. Ghose and S. Trageser, unpubl. data).
useTrade: The species and its parts and derivatives have been consumed historically at the local level, and the scales of this species are increasingly trafficked internationally to markets including China (Misra and Hanfee 2000; Mahmood et al. 2012, Challender and Waterman 2017, D'Cruze et al. 2018). The meat has been is consumed, e.g., in India (Kanagavel et al. 2016, D'Cruze et al. 2018) and its scales have been used in whole or powdered form in the preparation of traditional medicines and as curios in Pakistan (Roberts 1977). In India, there is evidence that tribal communities use the body parts including the Padhis, Saperas, Bawarias and Mongias (Sharma 2014). The meat, bile, scales and claws of pangolins are reportedly used by tribal communities including the Paaudi Bhuanya tribe of Odisha, Biate tribe of Assam, Katkaris folk of Maharashtra, Gond tribe of Madhya Pradesh, and Mizo ethnic group of Mizoram (Mohapatra et al. 2015).
conservationActions:
The species is present in a number of protected areas, including in Pakistan: Margalla Hills National Park (NP) (Mahmood et al. 2015a) and Kirthar NP; India: Badarama-Khalasuni Wildlife Sanctuary (WLS), Chandaka-Dampara WLS, Kuldiha WLS, Sunabeda WLS, Nandankanan WLS, Kothagarh WLS, Hadagarh WLS, Narsingarh WLS, Vallanadu WLS, and Phen WLS, Similipal Tiger Reserve (TR), Rajaji TR, Kalagarh TR, Bandhavgarh TR, Satpura TR, Pench TR, Mukundara Hills TR (Latafat and Sadhu 2016), the Similipal Biosphere Reserve, the Jhilmil jheel conservation reserve of Uttarakhand, Papikonda, Gir and Manas National Parks (Goswami and Ganesh 2014), and Sri Lanka: Yagirala Forest Reserve (Karawita et al. 2016), and Nepal: Bardia, Chitwan, Banke and Suklaphanta National Park and Para WLS (DNPWC and DOF 2018; H. Baral, unpubl. data).

The species is listed on CITES Appendix I and is a protected species in all range states but there remains a need to ensure that legislation affording the species protection is adequately enforced (Challender and Waterman 2017), and complementary interventions are needed including consumer behaviour change in key markets incentivising poaching and trafficking, and local community engagement at key sites - which need to be identified. 

Research is required into the population status of this species, including population parameters and its ability to withstand current and projected hunting and poaching pressures. More comprehensive research is also required to quantify hunting pressure and national and international utilisation of this species.

rationale: This species is mainly distributed in the major river systems of the Indus, Ganges and Brahmaputra Rivers of Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bhutan, and Bangladesh. Throughout its range, the species' population has been heavily impacted by illegal collection for meat consumption and for its skin. Given that the area where it occurs coincides with the highest human population densities in India, Nepal, and Bangladesh, habitat loss, degradation, and trade are major threats to the species. Overall, it is suspected that the population of the species has declined between 50–60% during the last three generations, and it is therefore listed as Endangered.
habitat:
This species is found in a number of humid habitats, including riverbanks, canals and rice fields, but predominantly in marshland (Visser 2004). It is absent from dry grassland or hot steppe, areas in which it has erroneously been assumed to occur (Visser 2004). It is mainly terrestrial, but is largely aquatic between June and October in the monsoon season (Visser 2004). In the dry season animals (between November and February) to its own burrows, termite mounds or crevices and cracks in the earth (Visser 2004). Its diet is known to include amphibian, reptile and bird eggs, insects and rodents (Visser 2004). They also are specialized for feeding on crabs. Animals of both sexes become sexually mature between their third and fourth year and females produce a single clutch (Visser 2004). Clutches of 4 to 30 eggs (mean 16) are laid in burrows in elevated areas between July and October (Visser 1985, Bennett 1988, Visser 2004). The length of the incubation period is 155 days at temperatures of >30°, however, can last more to 250 days if temperatures are 30°C and less (Auliya and Koch 2020).

Sexual maturity in both males and females is estimated at 3.5 years (range 2.5–4 yrs )and longevity in captivity is 10.6 years (Schleich and Kastle 2002). Assuming that animals in the wild may live less than in captivity, nine years is used in the estimation of generation length. Using the formula: age of first reproduction + (z * length of reproductive period), generation length is estimated at 5.7 years [3.5 + (0.4 * 5.5)]
threats:
The Gangetic River basin where this species occurs coincides with the highest human population densities in India, Nepal, and Bangladesh. Throughout its range, the species is heavily exploited for its skin and meat. It is also used along with other monitor lizards in traditional medicine (Shah and Tiwari 2004). Recreational killing in combination with persecution is also a major threat in both India and Nepal (Das 1988, Ghimire and Shah 2014). In India, one of the popular ways of hunting this species is by using dogs (A. Das pers. comm. 2019). Juveniles of the species are often predated by subsidized predators, such as domestic cats (A. Das pers. comm. 2019). The eggs are also consumed when found. The species is also hunted during popular hunting festivals in West Bengal (Bhattacharya et al. 2019).

Although this species has been reported from agricultural areas, mechanized agricultural practices, using heavy machinery, threaten subpopulations living in marginal habitats. In Bangladesh, agricultural activities are causing the degradation of breeding habitats (K. Hasan pers. comm. 2019).

It is frequently found in road kills (P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).

The species is largely confined to marshy and wetland habitats, which are under severe pressure from encroachment, land filling, and pollution (A. Das pers. comm. 2019). In Nepal it is restricted to small patches of habitat as a result of habitat encroachment, poaching and persecution (Karki and Bista 2008, Khatiwada and Ghimire 2009, Ghimire and Shah 2014).
population: There are no current data on population size and trends for this species. It is uncommon compared with the other monitor lizards in its range. The population is likely decreasing, mainly due to exploitation. In Bangladesh, the main reason for population decline is likely to be degradation of its breeding habitat. It is suspected that the population of the species has declined between 50–60% during the last three generations (17–18 years).
range: This species is confined to, and has a wide range on, the Indo-Gangetic Plain south of the Himalayas in eastern Pakistan (Rawalpindi, Multan, Sukkhur, Hyderabad, Sind Khan 1999), northern India, Nepal, south central Bhutan, and Bangladesh. Its distribution mainly follows the major river systems of the Indus, Ganges and Brahmaputra (Visser 2004).
useTrade: In India, this species is heavily exploited for international illegal trade (skin) as well as consumption (A. Das pers. comm. 2019). Among the monitor lizards, the skin of this species is considered the most valuable, due to its bright yellow colour (A. Das pers. comm. 2019). In Bangladesh, there is no report on trading, but it is locally consumed by tribal communities (K. Hasan pers. comm. 2019). There are no reports of consumption in Bhutan (J. Wangyal pers. comm. 2019). In Nepal, this species is heavily used for local consumption and traded illegally within the country (S. Bhattarai pers. comm. 2019). The skin is used for musical instruments (S. Bhattarai pers. comm. 2019). The eggs are also consumed when found.
conservationActions:
This species is included in CITES Appendix I. It is in Schedule I of Wildlife Protection Act of India (1972), National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1973 of Nepal, and is protected under the Wildlife (Conservation and Security) Act 2012 of Bangladesh.

Although it has been recorded from several protected areas throughout its range, it is only present in marshy areas, where they are also subjected to occasional poaching.

Conservation measures proposed include protection of wetlands and marshy areas, ground level enforcement of wildlife protection laws, identification of origin and rehabilitation of confiscated animals, education and awareness, coordination among law enforcement agencies.

Research into the life history and ecology of the species to improve conservation efforts is recommended. Regional awareness programmes have recently begun in India, and are needed in the species' other range states (Bhattacharya et al. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered applying criteria B1ab(iii) because its extent of occurrence is less than 3,000 km2, it is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This fossorial species has been encountered mainly in semi-evergreen forest, including forest edges in Amboli (Gower et al. 2016). One specimen in the type series was collected while digging soil and leaf litter in a shaded mixed plantation (Gower et al. 2016). Other specimens have been found near small streams and on roads, and were active mainly by day, typically in leaf litter or moist soil (Gower et al. 2016).
threats: Increasing urbanization and other drivers of substantial land use change are likely to threaten this species (Gower et al. 2016).
population: This is an uncommon species (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019), with little information about the population trend.
range: This snake species has a restricted range in the Western Ghats of northern Karnataka, Goa and southern Maharashtra, India, where it has been recorded between around 500 and 800 m asl (Gower et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species is known or expected to occur in a number of protected areas (e.g., Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary [Goa] and Kali Tiger Reserve [Karnataka]) (Gower et al. 2016). Additional surveys are needed to better understand the distribution of this newly described species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because the extent of occurrence is less than 100 km2 , it is known from a single location, there is an ongoing loss of suitable habitat as a result of agricultural development and forest fragmentation and degradation.
habitat: This species has been found in a matrix of cloud forest and plantations (Ganesh et al. 2014). Records have been taken from rainforest, including both the forest floor and beneath rocks near streams, and tea estates (Ganesh et al. 2014, Chaitanya et al. 2018). Individuals have been found in coffee plantations and beneath cement slabs (Ganesh et al. 2014).
threats: This species is impacted by habitat degradation, conversion of land to agricultural use (e.g. tea plantations). There are many roads within the distribution and roadkill of snakes is common in this area.
population: This species is not uncommonly recorded, but the population trend is not known.
range: This species is known only from the High Wavy-Varushanad-Periyar Mountains hill complex in Tamil Nadu, India, from around 1,300 and 1,600 m asl (Ganesh et al. 2014, Pyron et al. 2016, Chaitanya et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present in Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary and Srivillipathur Wildlife Sanctuary, both in Tamil Nadu. Further research is needed into the natural history and distribution of this species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is less than 100 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in two locations (one protected area one location outside of the protected area), and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to the expansion of tea plantations.
habitat: This is a diurnal, arboreal to semi-arboreal lizard known from disturbed high-elevation evergreen forest and along the edge of forest adjoining tea estates (Pal et al. 2018). The habitat image these authors provide indicates that the forest at the type locality is largely confined to narrow rows of trees between tea plantations. It is not present in the actual tea plantation (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). However, they can be frequently encountered in coffee and cardamon plantations (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). Animals have been recorded from shrubs, branches and tree trunks.
threats: Although this species shows some adaptability to habitat degradation and modification, the expansion of tea estates represents a threat to populations of this species.
population: It is a common species, but the population trend is unclear at present.
range: This species is so far known only from areas above 1,500 m asl in the Megamalai Hills in the southern Western Ghats, India (Pal et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present in the Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary. There is a need to limit additional conversion of suitable habitat to tea plantations. Additional field surveys are needed to better document the distribution of this lizard.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that, as presently understood, this lizard has am extent of occurrence of 3,540, km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur at two locations defined by a widespread threat from varied forms of habitat loss on the Bastar Plateau, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and likely in the area of occupancy. Further research may reveal that it is restricted to Bastar Plateau, which would strongly reduce the extent of occurrence.
habitat: This species is known from mixed deciduous forest dominated by Shorea robusta, Tectona grandis and bamboo species.  It has been found in caves and in areas with rocky boulders and stone structures. Adults have been found in old houses and juveniles on termite mounts and tree trunks.
threats: Forest fires and deforestation driven by agricultural conversion and human settlement are the major threats to this species (P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019). Fires are set annually throughout its range, and are likely to represent a threat as this species is a forest-dwelling lizard, but the frequency is not increasing and may be declining in some areas due to changes in management practices. Based on current knowledge, this is primarily a forest species mostly or entirely (should the Eastern Ghats record prove not to be conspecific) restricted to the Bastar Plateau, where habitat loss is widespread. A sister species, Hemidactylus sushilduttai, does however adapt to anthropogenic environments following habitat conversion, and it is possible this species has broader ecological tolerances than presently recognized (P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).
population: This is a locally common species, and the population appears to be generally stable where forest remains although there may be some decline (C. Srinivasulu and P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is known from three localities (a forest rest house near Kailash caves, Kanger Valley National Park;  Katamawas forest rest house, Bhadrimanu Jagdalpurl; and Sukma), all on the Bastar Plateau, Chatitsgarh, India (one taken at 464 km2). It is also known from a single locality in the Eastern Ghats: Khammam, Telangana (Mirza et al. 2017). It may occur at more localities within this region than presently known.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in Kanger Valley National Park, Chhattisgarh. Research is needed to clarify this species' distribution, population status and ecology, and taxonomic research is needed. Including this species in forest management plans is recommended, as it is largely endemic to the Bastar Plateau.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 116 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur at three locations defined by threats from mining and temple renovation work, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This is a rupiculous species whose known habitat comprises boulders and hillocks on both banks of the Tungabhadra River, in areas dominated by open scrub forests. It has been found mainly on boulders and on temple ruins, and not only in vegetated areas. The species was found n open granitic area in the Sandur Hills as well as in a forested tract (N.S. Achyuthan and S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019).
threats: Renovation activities in the temple may remove shelter sites by filling cracks within temple walls, and use of lime in restoration may reduce habitat suitability (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019). This species was first collected in darker areas of the temple complex, and may be affected by increased light pollution from light installations resulting from renovation (C.S. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019). Mining is widespread in the Sandur Hills, and this along with associated vehicle traffic has heavily degraded this area (C. Srinivasulu and N.S. Achthuyan pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is not particularly common at the type locality, where only three or four individuals were found (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019). It appears to be common in Sandur, Hospet, and Anegundi (N.S. Achyuthan and S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species was described from the Śiva temple ruins of Hampi World Heritage Site, Bellary Dist, Karnataka, India, at 442 m asl. (Srinivasulu et al. 2018). It is known from at least four point localities within the type locality. It has since been recorded from Sandur, around 20-25 km to the southeast (N.S. Achthuyan unpubl. data) and Anegundi further to the north of Tungabhadra (N.S. Achthuyan and C. Srinivasulu unpubl. data).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. While Hampi is in a cultural UNESCO World Heritage Site, it is an active archaeological site as well as a tourist site and activities within this area are likely to threaten this species. It is recommended that the species' needs are incorporated into the World Heritage Site management plan. Distributional research is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 1,062 km<sup>2</sup> (and based on known records a presumed area of occupancy of 16 km<sup>2</sup>), it is known from four locations and occurs as a severely fragmented population, and a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and apparently in the number of locations, has been observed at all localities
habitat: The type specimen was found on a stone wall near the road on the outskirts of Yercaud town (Das and Bauer 2000). Gravid females and juveniles have been recorded during September through December. It has been recorded from the outskirts of eucalyptus plantations and near building walls in well-vegetated campuses (coffee plantations). There is very little natural vegetation (tropical montane forest) remaining in this area, and this is highly fragmented. The species is more common within forest than outside (Ganesh and Arumagam 2016, Agarwal et al. 2019).
threats: The entire distribution lacks protected areas. Habitat alteration for plantations, and replacing existing plantations with developed areas, and light pollution. Harmful farming practices including use of pesticides which kill insect prey are increasing.
population: There is little information on the abundance or population trends for this species. Surveys from 2011 until at least 2016, indicate that the species is becoming rarer, including within plantations, and the number of known subpopulations is falling.
range: Until recently known only from high elevations (around 1,300 m) at the type locality, Yercaud Town, in the Shevaroyan (Shevaroy) Range, Salem District, Tamil Nadu (Das and Bauer 2000). Recent observation and collections at Kolli Hills and Pachamalai Hills Tamil Nadu extends its distribution range (Ganesh and Arumagam 2016, Agarwal et al. 2019). It is replaced by other species at lower elevations.  It has been observed at elevations between 1,300 and 1,500 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. The species is not known from any protected area. Habitat protection of remnant natural vegetation is urgently needed.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,149 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This is an arboreal species associated with tropical moist evergreen montane forest, although it can occur in modified areas. It inhabits shola vegetation, moss-covered earthen banks inside forest patches (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Siva 2020), human habitations, tea plantations and grassland (Princy et al. 2017). It is considered to tolerate a degree of anthropogenic disturbance but is elevation-dependent (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020). Breeding is by direct development.
threats:
Despite being a fairly adaptable species, the major threat is the conversion of native forest to intensively cultivated areas (including timber and non-timber plantations), and the associated pollution from pesticides and herbicides, which affect its ability to reproduce (Princy and Kannan 2015, S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Tourism is considered to be a major threat throughout its range and is causing species disturbance, vehicular noise is interfering with their calling behaviour, and plastic pollution is a problem for its habitat (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). In Mukurthi National Park, the creation of fire lines is also a threat to the species and its habitat (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020). 

In the Nilgiri Hills, the temperature is has increased in the last decade which has affected the shola forest habitat and allowed the encroachment of invasive plant plantations (eucalyptus, lantana, acacia,wattle, pinewoods) which has reduced the level of the water table, as well as causing changes in the rainfall patterns (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Climate change is also likely to cause habitat shifting, and subpopulations that already exist in higher elevations may be lost as they have no habitat to migrate to. Deformities and malformations have been recorded due to causes that are unknown at present, although are similar to cases in other species in different regions of the world that are caused by increased UV levels (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020).

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop November 2020).
population: It is commonly seen in the Nilgiri Hills (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001) and is common throughout its range. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in the Nilgiri Hills of southern Western Ghats in Tamil Nadu State, India, and surrounding areas in Coonoor, Kothagiri, Naduvattam, Avalanche, Parsons Valley (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021), Udhagamandalam (Princy and Kannan 2015), Ooty, Emerald, Mukurthi (Princy et al. 2017, Siva 2020, Garg et al. 2021), many of which are in Mukurthi National Park. It has also been recorded from Silent Valley National Park (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020, Garg et al. 2021) and now also Vellarimala in Wayanad District (Garg et al. 2021), both in Kerala State. It occurs between 1,780-2,465 m asl (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001, Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Princy et al. 2017, Siva 2020). It is unlikely to range much more widely than is currently known (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). It occurs in three to five threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,149 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Action In-Place 
This species occurs in Mukurthi National Park and Silent Valley National Park, with more than 50% of the population occurring in these areas (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). The species was included in field studies by Biju (1998-2001).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, as well as the education of tourists on their disturbance behaviours which would also be beneficial for this species (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Other recommended conservation measures are to implement a long term management project, research on the impact of pesticides at the subpopulation level, and public awareness programs to prevent killing (Princy and Kannan 2015).

Research Needed
Further research is required on the effects of Bd and into the deformities that have been observed in this species (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Population monitoring is also recommended (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,746 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: It is a canopy species, and has been found in primary forest, forest patches bordering tea plantations, and secondary vegetation adjoining the forest along the Ghat road (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020). The type specimens were recorded in the fringes of natural vegetation near a tea plantation, always on leaves and twigs of Lantana thickets (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Despite specimens being found in the proximity of tea plantations, they were never reported inside. It may tolerate a degree of habitat disturbance, but not severe habitat loss and disturbance (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). It may require a larger area with good foliage for egg-laying due to its larger size. It has been observed in higher numbers in primary forests compared to forest patches demonstrating a preference for undisturbed habitats (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). It is easier for it to be recorded from its calling rather than observations (R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threat to this species is habitat clearance for tea and eucalyptus plantations, all the more concerning since there are no other areas of suitable habitat known in the surrounding region. Pesticide use could be a problem for species found in forest patches within plantations (S.R. Chandramouli and S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020). Road mortalities may be a problem for this species (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). It is thought that 50% of the population may be threatened by these threats (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). Climate change is a potential future threat, and may cause habitat shifting which may result in the loss of subpopulations in higher elevations with no available habitat for it to migrate to (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been confirmed in the genus, with morbidity observed but no mortalities to date, but further studies required to investigate full effects on this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
population: It is considered to be uncommon, with five individuals seen at a time (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020). More than half (>50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal. The population is therefore considered to be severely fragmented. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species when first described was known from its type locality, a tea estate close to Munnar at 1,500 m asl, along the Ghat road to Devikulam, as well as from Devikulam, both in the state of Kerala in the southern Western Ghats of India (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is now also known in Kerala from Eravikulam National Park (Das et al. 2018, Garg et al. 2021), Chinnar, Kadalar, Mathikettan, Mattupetti, Upper Manalar and Vaguvarai in the Idukki District (Garg et al. 2021). Additionally it has also been recorded in Tamil Nadu State in Valparai within the Anamalai Tiger Reserve (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020) and Meghamalai in Theni District (Garg et al. 2021). It has been recorded between 1,400–2,000 m asl (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Das et al. 2018). It is thought to be restricted to its known range but may be found in between in areas and in the adjacent area of Palni Hills (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,746 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Eravikulam National Park and Anamalai Tiger Reserve, in which about 50% of the population is thought to occur within these areas (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, including improved management of the Tiger Reserve.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution and the effects of Bd and climate change. Population monitoring is also recommended (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,166 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This species occurs in grasslands where it lives in shrubs, on earthen banks (Biju and Bossuyt 2009), and under the vegetation and small patches of shola vegetation (Siva 2020). The species has also been recorded in rural gardens, but this is marginal habitat used for foraging (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). It is therefore thought to tolerate only a degree of habitat modification (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). They undergo direct development and hatching of froglets takes place after 19 days (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). 

According to Kumar et al. (2017) and Princy et al. (2017), it is the main diet for predators like Ahaetulla perroteti and Salea horsfieldii because of its smaller size (Siva 2020).
threats:
The major threat to this high-elevation species is climate change, as shifts in monsoon patterns risk changing the temperature and humidity it requires, and can also result in landslides that can affect large areas. Habitat destruction and degradation is also a major threat caused by conversion to eucalyptus, wattle, and pine plantations for timber, the cutting of fire lines to manage fire events in grasslands, the expansion of human settlements, cattle grazing, agricultural expansion, and pollution from pesticides and herbicides associated with agricultural activities which affect its ability to reproduce (Princy and Kannan 2015). Plastic pollution from tourism and road mortalities are additional threats (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). The proximity of human habitation to the species' grassland habitat has also introduced domestic, feral cats which have been observed preying upon this species (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). In Mukurthi National Park, the creation of fire lines is also a threat to the species and its habitat (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020). 

In the Nilgiri Hills, the temperature has increased in the last decade which has affected the shola forest habitat and allowed the encroachment of invasive plant plantations (eucalyptus, lantana, acacia,wattle, pinewoods) which has reduced the level of the water table, as well as causing changes in the rainfall patterns (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Climate change is also likely to cause habitat shifting, and subpopulations that already exist in higher elevations may be lost as they have no habitat to migrate to. Deformities and malformations have been recorded due to causes that are unknown at present, although are similar to cases in other species in different regions of the world that are caused by increased UV levels (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020 - e.g. Blaustein and Johnson 2003 and Romansic et al. 2009).

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
population: It is one of the most common species in the Nilgiri Hills (Biju 2001). However, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing. The population is considered to be severely fragmented as more than half (> 50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal.
range: This species occurs in the Nilgiri Hills of the Western Ghats in Tamil Nadu State, India, and surrounding areas in Coonoor, Kothagiri, Naduvattam, Avalanche, Parsons Valley (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021), Udhagamandalam (Princy and Kannan 2015), Emerald (Princy et al. 2017, Siva 2020), Ooty, Mukurthi (Princy et al. 2017, Siva 2020, Garg et al. 2021) and Pykara (Garg et al. 2021), many of which are in Mukurthi National Park. It has also been recorded from Silent Valley National Park in Palakkad District in Kerala State (Garg et al. 2021). It occurs between 1,780-2,465 m asl (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001, Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Princy et al. 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,166 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in a number of protected areas in the Nilgiri Hills, including Mukurthi National Park and Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve (Princy and Kannan 2015) as well as Silent Valley National Park in Kerala.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, as well as the education of tourists on their disturbance-causing behaviours, which would also be beneficial for other species (India Red List Assessment Workshop November 2020). In particular, the regulation of domestic animals and livestock is needed to decrease their impact on the species and its habitat.

Research Needed
Further research on its life history, population size, distribution, and trends, and the effects of Bd, climate change and into the deformities that have been observed in this species is required. Population monitoring is also recommended (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,376 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, it is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in isolated shrubs surrounded by or near plantations (mostly tea plantations), or in degraded tropical moist evergreen forest areas (S.D. Biju pers. comm. October 2011). It has been recorded within plantations (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). During the non-breeding season it can be found under leaf litter and logs in secondary vegetation, whereas during the breeding season it can be found on vegetation up to 1 m above the ground (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It has been found on grasses and bushes in marshy grassland ecosystems, vayals and open grasslands, however, not a single encounter was observed in the surrounding evergreen forest patches, likely to be an indication that this species is a vayal specialist (Rajkumar et al. 2016). It is unlikely to tolerate habitat loss and disturbance (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). It is presumed to breed by direct development, as with its congeners.
threats:
Deforestation through conversion of land to agricultural use and urban development caused the disappearance of this species in Bodanaikanur (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Major threats to this species in Vandiperiyar and Vagaman are extensive tea cultivation and emerging tourism activity, which is increasing in popularity in areas, such as resort construction in the forested areas of Vagaman (S.D. Biju pers. comm. October 2011, Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). In the Sabarimalai area, a mass pilgrimage of millions of people occurs on an annual basis which causes pollution to terrestrial habitat, species disturbance, and there is an annual burning of the 1 km2 of grassland for use as a seating area by the pilgrims (Rajkumar K.P.  pers. comm. October 2020). Off-roading vehicles for tourism is a threat in Sathram (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). Climate change is a potential future threat which may result in the shifting of habitat, and subpopulations that already exist in higher elevations may be lost as they have no habitat to migrate to (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). 

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
population: It was described in 1891 and at the time of the 2004 assessment it was known only from the holotype. However, it was rediscovered in 2004 from Vandiperiyar, some 70 km northwest of the type locality (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Compared to other frogs of the same genus from the Western Ghats, this species is considered to be extremely rare as only eleven individuals could be found in Vandiperiyar and Vagaman after successive nights of continuous search in those areas in 2004 and 2006 (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It can be considered locally common, but is restricted by its habitat requirements (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). It is thought that at least 50% (possibly up to 60%) of the population is isolated in Periyar Tiger Reserve, and there will be no gene flow occurring between this subpopulation and those in Vandiperiyar and Vagaman due to areas of unsuitable habitat conditions and elevations existing in between them (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). While gene flow and migration of individuals is thought to be possible between those subpopulations in Vandiperiyar and Vagaman (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020), the population is considered to be severely fragmented overall. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is known from the type locality of Bodanaikanur (i.e.'Bodinayakkanur, Travancore') in Tamil Nadu state, Vandiperiyar and Vagaman, both in Kerala state (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021), Periyar Tiger Reserve, nearly 40 km from Vagaman (S.D. Biju pers. comm. February 2014, Garg et al. 2021), and Meghamalai in Theni District in Tamil Nadu (Garg et al. 2021). It is also known from Bodimettu, the area at higher elevations near the type locality in Tamil Nadu, where it was recorded in 2018 (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). In Periyar Tiger Reserve it occurs in Uppuppara, Gavi, Upper Manalar, Eravangalar, Mangaladevi, Kumarikulam, Moolavaika and Chokkampatti (Rajkumar et al. 2016). It occurs between 700-1,802 m asl (Rajkumar et al. 2016, Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020).  It is restricted to its known range, and further surveys south of Periyar Tiger Reserve have not recorded this species (Rajkumar K.P. pers. comm. October 2020). It occurs in three threat-defined locations, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,640 km2, and its area of occupancy (AOO) is ca. 100 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Periyar Tiger Reserve, in which at least 50% of the population occurs within this area (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). 

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, as well as continued maintenance of protected area where it exists (Rajkumar K.P. and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020).

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, natural history, and the effects of climate change and Bd. Research on the habitat preferences and distribution of this taxon, particularly through a detailed survey in related habitats of Periyar Tiger Reserve, and habitat conservation of the vayal ecosystem in Periyar Tiger Reserve (Rajkumar et al. 2016). Population monitoring is also recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,920 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in primary evergreen montane forest and disturbed sholas (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020), a type of high-altitude evergreen forest found only in the southern portion of the Western Ghats. Individuals have been recorded near secondary forest and tea and eucalyptus plantations after heavy rain, from about 1 m above the ground, from thickets of Lantana or leaves of Ageratina adenophora (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). In Munnar, it has been observed in tea plantations (K.P. Rajkumar pers. comm. October 2020). It is unlikely for this species to tolerate severe habitat disturbance and loss (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). It breeds by direct development (Biju, S.D. pers. comm. December 2010).
threats:
This species occurs in a highly degraded area being used extensively for large-scale tea, eucalyptus and wattle plantations (Biju S.D. pers. comm. December 2010). Pesticide use may also be considered a threat to this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). Road development and widening is a problem within the species range and will lead to the removal of vegetation (R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). Landslides are a threat to the subpopulations occurring in Munnar (K.P. Rajkumar, S.R. Ganesh and R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). The tourism industry in this region has also experienced considerable development and could be a potential threat to this species, although it is currently not very intensive (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). Climate change is a potential future threat, and may cause habitat shifting which may result in the loss of subpopulations in higher elevations with no available habitat for it to migrate to (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been confirmed in the genus, with morbidity observed but no mortalities to date, but further studies required to investigate full effects on this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
population: It is considered to be an uncommon species, which can be difficult to locate due to their habitat preferences of overhanging vegetation on hill slopes (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from Munnar (1,410 m asl), in Idukki district, in the state of Kerala, within the Western Ghats mountain range in India (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Survey efforts in neighbouring areas could find no individuals between the time of description and 2011 (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). Since 2011 it has been recorded in several new sites in Tamil Nadu and Kerala. In Kerala it has been recorded from Eravikulam National Park (Das et al. 2018, Garg et al. 2021), Upper Manalar in Periyar Tiger Reserve (K.P. Rajkumar pers. comm. October 2020, Garg et al. 2021), Chinnar, Devikulam, Kadalar, Mathikettan, Mattupetti and Vaguvarai (Garg et al. 2021), all in Idukki District. In Tamil Nadu State it has been recorded from Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary (Chaitanya et al. 2018, Garg et al. 2021), Valparai in Anamalai Tiger Reserve, and Sivagiri Hills in Srivilliputhur Wildlife Sanctuary (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020). It may occur more widely in places such as Palni Hills (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020), however, not in intervening areas between the known localities as they are unsuitable elevations for this species. It occurs between 1,400–1,800 m asl (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. October 2020, Garg et al. 2021). It occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,920 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in Eravikulam National Park (Das et al. 2018), Srivilliputhur Wildlife Sanctuary, Anamalai Tiger Reserve, Periyar Tiger Reserve and Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary, where at least 50% of the population is present in these areas (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, population status, ecology, and the effects of climate change and Bd. Population monitoring is also recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 130 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is known at the type locality from an abandoned tea plantation and nearby disturbed evergreen forest patches (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Biju S.D. pers. comm. May 2011). Individuals have been found on tea plant leaves (average height of about 2 m above the ground), and on the ground, either on the surface of dead leaves or beneath leaves or logs (Inger et al. 1984 in Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is unknown to what level this species can tolerate habitat disturbance and loss, however it is more common outside tea plantations so is thought to require canopy cover (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). It breeds by direct development (S.D. Biju pers. comm. December 2010).
threats:
The area where this species occurs is used extensively for tea and arecanut plantations and this species has only been recorded from lightly disturbed areas or neighbouring forest. Pesticide use is thought to be a major threat (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). Road mortalities occur in Ponmudi, which may be a threat to this species due to their habitats proximity to the roads, although their small size makes it difficult to verify (R. Suyesh pers. comm. October 2020). The collection of leaf litter and setting of fires may be a threat to this species (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. October 2020). 

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
population: It is common and found in good numbers. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known only from its type locality of Ponmudi and the vicinity in the Thiruvananthapuram District of Kerala, India from 600-980 m asl (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It has now also been recorded from Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary in Kollam District and Bonacaud in Thiruvananthapuram (Garg et al. 2021). It may also occur in Peppara Wildlife Sanctuary, but is considered to be fairly range-restricted (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020). It occurs in three threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 130 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Ponmudi Reserve Forest, which does not have the highest level of protection, and the current habitat patches are not safeguarded (S.D. Biju pers. comm. January 2011). Recently it has been recorded from Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary (Garg et al. 2021)

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection and management is required.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, natural history and the effects of Bd. Population monitoring is also recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 682 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is known from a plantation and neighbouring disturbed forest. Individuals were collected on leaves 1-1.5 m high, near an abandoned eucalyptus plantation next to Coonoor Sims Park (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). All specimens were collected during rain in the late evening (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Given that the species is locally abundant and that it occurs in some disturbed environments, this seems to suggest that it is tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance. Like other congeners, this species breeds by direct development.
threats: The area where this species  occurs is used extensively for large-scale eucalyptus plantations, and associated pesticide use is a threat to this species which is found on lower vegetation where it is applied (S.D. Biju pers. comm. April 2021). There is also a developing tourism industry in the region.
population: It is considered to be locally abundant, but it is patchily distributed. Despite being tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from the type locality of Coonoor, as well as Kothagiri, both in the Nilgiri Hills in Tamil Nadu state, India (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is now also recorded it from Naduvattam and Pykara, also in the Nilgiri Hills (Garg et al. 2021). It occurs at 1,780 m asl  (Biju and Bossuyt 2009) to 2,083 m asl (Princy et al. 2017). It is likely to be restricted to this area, as there have been significant surveys in surrounding areas and it has not been recorded to date (S.D. Biju pers. comm. April 2021). It occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 682 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur in any protected areas.


Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required.


Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 301 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in evergreen forest patches (Biju and Bossuyt 2009), where it occurs 1.5-5 m above the ground in the canopy (Garg et al. 2021). Afthab et al. (2018) found it in the hollow fallen tree in a coffee plantation. Individuals are nocturnal and have been found in 1 m tall trees (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is usually found in the forest patches around tea plantations, suggesting that it is not tolerant of habitat loss (S. Garg and S.D. Biju pers. comm. February 2021). It is a direct developing species.
threats: Habitat loss and fragmentation due to small and large-scale agricultural practices and due to infrastructure development and construction for tourism over the past five years are major threats to this species (S.D. Biju pers. comm. December 2010).
population: It is considered to be rare since it was only found in its type locality despite intensive survey effort in suitable neighbouring areas (S.D. Biju per. comm. December 2010). The original description was based on four individuals recorded on 20 September 1998 (Biju and Bossuyt 2009), and an additional specimen was discovered during systematic surveys carried out between March and April 2018, approximately 9.5 km from the type locality (Afthab et al. 2018). Additional specimens have also been recorded by Garg et al. (2021). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known only from its type locality of Kaikatti (at 1,000 m asl), in the Nelliyampathi Hills, in Palakkad District, Kerala, in the Western Ghats mountain range in India (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is also known from one specimen collected at Anamada, also in the Nelliyampathi Hills (Afthab et al. 2018), and Chimmini in Thrissur District (Garg et al. 2021). It occurs between 600-1,000 m asl (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Afthab et al. 2018). It is unlikely to occur more widely than is currently known. It occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 301 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur within any protected area (S.D. Biju pers. comm. December 2010). The habitat is within a reserve forest which is not protected for this species.

Conservation Needed
Habitat conservation should be a priority for this species, given its current known distribution. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' population status and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,565 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is known from evergreen forest (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Individuals have been found during rainy evenings  on leaves or stems of undergrowth, 1-2 m high, and 2-3 m off the ground (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). Individuals have been observed along the roadside, however this observation was on a road within a protected area (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020). It has not been observed in any disturbed habitats to date, and due to the species' large body size it is not thought to be tolerant of a lot of habitat disturbance and loss (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020). Juveniles have been found at the end of September on the ground under the leaf litter, away from any permanent water sources (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). This species breeds by direct development, as with its congeners.
threats:
The major threat to this species is habitat fragmentation due to small and large-scale tea and cardamom plantations (S.D. Biju pers. comm. May 2011). These plantations are not actively expanding but are well-established within the species range, and the associated pesticide use will be a major threat ( S.R. Ganesh and  S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). 

Climate change is a potential future threat which may result in the shifting of habitat, and subpopulations that already exist in higher elevations may be lost as they have no habitat to migrate to (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been found in other species of the genus, so chytridiomycosis may be a potential threat for this species but further research is required (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
population: This species is considered to be rare, as for a while it could only be found at its type locality despite intense searches throughout neighbouring areas (S.D. Biju pers. comm. December 2010). The population is considered to be severely fragmented as more than half (> 50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, its population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from Andiparai Shola, municipality of Valparai in Coimbatore district, Tamil Nadu State, India (Biju and Bossuyt 2009). It is now also known from many other localities within the central and western portions of Anamalai Tiger Reserve, at elevations between 1,000-1,600 m asl (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. November 2020, Garg et al. 2021), as well as Eravikulam National Park, Mathikettan Shola National Park and Kadalar in Idukki District, Parambikulam in Palakkad District, and Malakkappara-Sholayar in Thrissur District in Kerala State (Garg et al. 2021). It may occur a little more widely than is currently known, but further surveys are required (S.R. Ganesh and S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. November 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,565 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Anamalai Tiger Reserve, Eravikulam National Park and Mathikettan Shola National Park.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs is needed.

Research Needed
Further research on its distribution, life history, and the effects of Bd and climate change are required.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 671 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from four to five threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
habitat: This primarily arboreal species inhabits mid- to high-elevation evergreen forests, where it has been recorded near seasonal highland swamps or marshes. It is unlikely to tolerate any level of habitat disturbance or loss (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). It breeds from April to July, when hundreds of males migrate and aggregate in the periphery of dry moist swamp beds perching on shrubs and bushes. Eggs are laid scattered on moist soil or grassy substrate; clutches comprise 175 eggs. Posterior rain events allow the water level to rise due and therefore the completion of the life cycle (Abraham et al. 2013).
threats:
Habitat loss and degradation due to agricultural development, in particular cardamon and tea plantations, are major threats to the taxon (Abraham et al. 2013). Pesticide use is also considered as a threat (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). Monsoon changes associated with climate change could be a possible future threat, which may affect the breeding activity of this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop November 2020).

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) is considered a possible threat, but further research is required to understand the full effects on this species (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020).
population: It is considered to be common during their breeding season (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). Outside of the breeding season, it is found in the canopy or under logs (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species endemic to the southern Western Ghats of India occurs in the Valparai Plateau of the Anamalai Hills in Tamil Nadu State, and throughout the western slopes of the Eravikulam Plateau, where it has been recorded in the Mankulam Forest Division of Idukki District and the higher parts of the Malayattoor Forest Division of Ernakulam District, in Kerala State (Zachariah et al. 2011, Abraham et al. 2013). It is also known from Periyar Tiger Reserve and Eravikulam National Park (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). It occurs between 1,000–1,700 m asl. (Abraham et al. 2013, S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). It is likely to occur more widely in between its known localities (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). It occurs in four to five threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 671 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Indira Gandhi Tiger Reserve, Eravikulam National Park and Periyar Tiger Reserve, with more than 50% of the population occurring in these areas (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020). 

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection and habitat restoration programs are of particular importance for this species (Abraham et al. 2013).

Research Needed
Further research on its distribution, and the effects of Bd and climate change are also required. Population monitoring is also recommended (S. Das pers. comm. November 2020).

rationale: Bhutanitis ludlowi has been listed as Endangered B2ab(ii,iii). The species has a low extent of occurrence of approximately 47,000 km2, however only exists in a few locations (<5) and has a restricted area of occupancy of approximately 48 km2. The species is also listed under Appendix II of CITES, and is internationally traded on account of its rarity in the wild. And despite existing in known sanctuaries and protected areas with protected status across the Bhutanese range, there is evidence of the species being subjected to habitat loss and habitat disturbance (due to agriculture, poaching, and climate change) across its range in Bhutan and Arunachal Pradesh, India. There is also limited information on the population trends of this species. To safeguard the future population of this species therefore, further conservation planning is required. Improved monitoring of population trends and applying butterfly surveys could help further in maintaining the species population.
habitat:
The Trashiyangtse Valley (where the species was recorded) runs north-to-south in the Eastern Himalayas, with elevations reaching over 5,000 m (Wangdi et al. 2012). Aristolochia griffithii is the primary foodplant for this species (Harada et al. 2011). In Bhutan, this plant occurs in montane regions (1,800-3,000 m), surrounded by cooler broadleaved forests (including a mixture of evergreen oak and mixed fir) (Harada et al. 2012). The host plant is an evergreen woody climber (Harada et al. 2012). The elevation occupied by this species exhibits alpine conditions (that also stretch to the lower foothills of the Himalayas), with hardwood forests also dominating the area (FAO/UNEP 1981). Blue pine and deciduous forests are also be found within the area (FAO/UNEP 1981, Harada et al. 2012).  Although early recordings showed the species to occur in gaps along primary forests in Bhutan, secondary forests now dominate the valley and are therefore the primary habitat of this species (Harada et al. 2012). Across its occurrence in Arunachal Pradesh, the habitat is mostly mountainous, containing tropical evergreen, semi-evergreen, deciduous, pine, temperate, and alpine forests (Department of Environment and Forest 2018). Males have been recorded from the beginning of August and females were observed from mid-August (Wangdi et al. 2012).
The life cycle of the Ludlow’s Bhutan Glory is completed in 367 days in three stages (ex-situ; http://www.kuenselonline.com/bhutan-becomes-the-first-country-to-record-ludlows-bhutan-glory-life-cycle/): eggs hatch at 14-18 days, the larval stage takes around five months and the pupal stage around six months; after 188 days, the adult butterfly emerges from the chrysalis.
threats: There is very little information on the threats to this species in the literature. Although Bhutan is one of the best forested areas within the Himalayan mountain region, resources have been eroded due to unregulated grazing, forest fires, and high consumption of wood (used for fuel and construction) (Collins and Morris 1985). Other threats to the species include conversion of habitat to arable land (with forest degradation thought to occur in over 80% of forest area) and climate change (due to its land-locked nature and physical topography) (National Environment Commission 2016). Wildlife could therefore be affected, with the effects thought to be unrecoverable due to the nature and topography of the Himalayan region (Collins and Morris 1985). However, approximately 2.8 million hectares (out of a land area of 3.8 million ha) is covered by forest, with forest loss (with 30% canopy density) only accounting for 22,800 hectares between 2001-2017 (Hansen et al. 2013). The future of the species is also thought to be affected by poachers (Harada et al. 2012), following its rediscovery and known rarity. Across the state of Arunachal Pradesh, similar threats have been reported, for example, due to growing populations, livestock farming, infrastructure construction, conversion of forests to developed areas and low awareness of forestry (Department of Environment and Forest 2018).
population: The species is thought to be rare and uncommon (Singh and Chib 2015, Sondhi and Kunte 2016). Further information is required regarding trends of the global population of this species.
range: The species was previously only recorded from the Trashiyangsi Valley in Northeastern Bhutan, collected between 1933-1934, where it had been found at elevations of 2,300-2,500 m (Collins and Morris 1985). The species was rediscovered in 2012 (Harada et al. 2012) when it was found in a small area around Tarphel, Trashiyangsi Valley, at 2,300-2,500 m (Wangdi et al. 2012). The species has also been reported from western Arunachal Pradesh, India (Varshney and Smetacek 2015, Singh and Sondhi 2016) at Eaglenest Sanctuary and between Dirang and Sange in the West Kameng District, Arunachal Pradesh, India (at elevations of approximately 1,700 m) (Sondhi and Kunte 2016).The species is now considered to be endemic to these areas (Singh and Chib 2015). Its estimated extent of occurrence is approximately 47,000 km2. Its area of occupancy is however likely to be much more restricted (at approximately 48 km2) since it is only known to occur in a few localities across this range.
useTrade: This species is listed under CITES Appendix II (CITES 2017). The species was traded in 2012 (CITES Trade Database 2018) when two bodies (found during the rediscovery) were exported from Bhutan to Japan, collected from the wild and used for educational purposes. The future of the species is thought to be affected by poachers (Harada et al. 2012).
conservationActions:
The species was listed as Insufficiently Known in a 1985 swallowtail assessment (Collins and Morris 1985). The species was subsequently reassessed as VU under criterion D2 (Gimenez Dixon 1996). The species is considered Endangered in Bhutan (Wangdi and Sherub 2012). The species has been reported from Eaglenest Sanctuary in Arunachal Pradesh, although it is stated to be rare (Sondhi and Kunte 2016). It has also been found in Bumdeling Wildlife Sanctuary (BWS) in Bhutan (Singh and Chib 2015). 

The species is listed under CITES Appendix II (CITES 2017) alongside all members of the genus. The species is also protected under schedules of the Forest Nature and Conservation Rules of Bhutan 2006 and is declared as a National Butterfly of Bhutan (Singh and Chib 2015). The forests in which the species occurs have also been managed under traditional forestry management by the local villagers, and are thus conserved by the Bhutanese people (Harada et al. 2012). Captive breeding programmes and conservation management plans have been suggested for the future protection of this species (Harada et al. 2012). Out of approximately 3.8 million hectares that covers the Bhutanese country, approximately 2.8 million hectares is also covered by trees, with tree loss (with 30% canopy density) only accounting for 22,800 hectares between 2001-2017 (Hansen et al. 2013). Conservation measures already established could therefore be a significant contributor towards minimal tree loss.

Past status assessments, at times when the species had not yet been rediscovered, concluded that the presence of the species within the Trashiyangsi Valley needed to be reconfirmed (Collins and Morris 1985). Although now rediscovered in the valley, additional surveys are required to establish whether the species occurs at other loaclities in the Bhutan and Arunachal Pradesh, India. Around 20% (9,213 km2) of Bhutan is protected by wildlife sanctuaries and reserves; for example, the Jigme Dorji wildlife sanctuary (covering 7,900 km2) extends along the northern border of Bhutan. A butterfly survey within this and other sanctuaries would therefore be useful.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered, due to a combination of habitat loss and severe pressures from hunting, causing a reduction in the population of more than 50% over three generations (approximately 24 years). The species is also predicted to decline by more than 50% over the next three generations across its entire range due to continuing hunting pressures and loss of habitat. Hunted animals are used for traditional medicines, and for national and international trade in pets and tourist photo props. Bengal Slow Lorises are also caught for meat, and their body parts are used as tourist key rings. The combined effects of forest loss of more than 30% over the last 24 years, and disappearance of the species in several locations in countries like Cambodia due to hunting, and continued threats into the future are factors determining the declines in the past, continuing and suspected declines in the future.
habitat:
This is an arboreal, nocturnal species that inhabits tropical evergreen rainforest, semi-evergreen forest, and mixed deciduous forest. In Viet Nam it is found only in secondary forests, and on the edge of primary forests; the species also occurs in agricultural fields and plantations (V. Thanh pers. comm., Pliosongnoen et al. 2010, Kumar et al. 2014). It ranges from sea level (U. Streicher pers. comm.) up to 2,400 m (Choudhury 2001). In Cambodia, N. bengalensis has been observed in dipterocarp and evergreen forest (Mould 2013, Eam Sam Un 2014) and community forests (Eam Sam Un 2014). In India, they are found in semi-evergreen, evergreen and mixed deciduous forest (Das 2005, 2009, 2014; Pliosungnoen 2014). In Laos, the species is found often in protected evergreen forests (Evans 2000, Coudrat 2012), and have also been observed in plantation forests (Pliosungnoen unpublished data) and bamboo stands (Streicher pers. comm). It can live in heavily disturbed agricultural areas if suitable foods are available.

The diet of the Bengal Slow Loris consists of nectar, plant bark, fruits and small invertebrates; the majority of their wild diet comprises plant exudates and this is a key staple year round (Swapna et al. 2009, Pliosungnoen et al. 2010, Das et al. 2014). Nycticebus bengalensis are venomous, as are other members of the slow loris genus (Nekaris et al. 2013).

This animal's life span is about 15 years, and generation time is 7-8 years. Females give birth to one offspring per litter once every two years in semi-wild conditions (Rowe 1996). In captivity, this rate may be slightly higher (U. Streicher pers. comm).
threats: The major threats that this species' habitat faces include farming, timber removal, human settlement, road building, dams, power lines, fragmentations, soil loss and erosion, and deliberately set fires. It is hunted and traded for food, traditional "medicine", sport, and as pet (Molur et al. 2003, Nekaris and Nijman 2007, V. Thanh and U. Streicher pers. comm., Kumar et al. 2014). Road kills represent another threat to this species (Rhadakrishna et al. 2006). It is also threatened for the tourist photo prop trade across some of its range, particularly in Thailand, where 94% of individuals photographed in the photo prop trade from Patong beach were N. bengalensis (Osterberg and Nekaris 2015); this trade is extending into Europe, in countries such as Turkey. The species has been observed for sale in markets for traditional medicine purposes at Mong La, on the Chinese border of Myanmar (Nijman et al. 2013), where its arms are also sold as key rings (Nijman et al. 2015) and is also known to be sold for use in traditional medicine elsewhere (Cambodia, Viet Nam and India) (Starr et al. 2010).
